I have already had a go at her about how she scared older peopleâshe spent the whole of October and November scaring older people about our policy. On 13 May 1998, the shadow minister for social security and the aged, Jenny Macklin, issued a press release entitled `National network of 160 rehabilitation services under threat'. She stated:

Just when you thought that it couldn't get any worse for people with disabilities trying to get a job in the new employment services market, the government has introduced a Bill which threatens the quality and accessibility of employment services provided by the CRS. The Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service Reform Bill contains provisions which will see the CRS and its network of 160 services across Australia partially privatised by 1999.

The truth: the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service will not be partially privatised by 1999. Ms Macklin was wrong when she says that the bill partially privatises the CRS. The bill does not contain any provisions to privatise the CRS in any way. The bill covers administrative measures necessary to establish the CRS as a new organisation dedicated to the delivery of first-class rehabilitation services to its clients.

I can tell you that it has not been doing that. Despite the best intentions of the staff of the CRS when it was under Labor, there was disorganisation, there was a lack of coordination and it did not fulfil its mission. Ms Macklin went on to say:
The effect of this will be felt hardest in the bush, where over 80 of the CRS outlets are based and where the CRS is the only provider of rehabilitation services around for miles.

The truth: there are no plans to withdraw CRS services from current areas. CRS will continue to provide quality services in regional and remote areas under its contractual arrangements with the department.
What else did she say? Ms Macklin said:
And we have to consider just how many of the 1,400 CRS workers the Government intends to sack as a result of this measure.

The truth: Ms Macklin is wrong when she suggests that many of the 1,400 CRS staff will be sacked as a result of these measures. CRS staff will be transferred to the new company under the Public Service Act with their existing entitlements, and they will have mobility rights providing them with the rights of return to the Public Service. Were there any apologies from Ms Macklin? Were there any retractions of the release? No. The Australian public deserves better than this.

What about Labor on child care? One of the more persistent myths peddled by the Australian Labor Party relates to child care. A typical example was found in a press release put out by Senator Neal on 17 May 1998. She said:
The child care sector is in crisis and parents are leaving in droves because they can't afford child care.

The truth: recent ABS figures show that more women with dependent children are now working either full-time or part-time than three years agoâan increase of 36,000 since April 1995âand the labour force participation has remained stable at around 59 per cent. There were no retractions from Senator Neal. Do not worry about truth getting in the way of a good story. Just say that women are leaving the work force in droves. Do not worry about the ABS statistics; just make up a story that fits your argument whether it is the truth or not.

What about pharmaceuticals? I think one of the most despicable things I have seen was a pamphlet put out by Mr Michael Lee, the shadow minister for health. How can he claim to be the alternative health minister when he frightens older people in this way? The pamphlet was about the changes to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. The pharmaceutical benefits scheme was increasing at a rate that was totally unsustainableâsomething like 15 per cent per annum. Drugs that ought to have been available to people with multiple sclerosis and to people with Parkinson's diseaseâand I think there was one other very expensive drug that was needed for people with advanced breast cancerâwere not on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme.

By bringing in some of these changes to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, Dr Wooldridge enabled those drugs to go on the PBS for those people who deserved themâfor those people whose whole lives were ruined by their Parkinsonian tremor; for people with multiple sclerosis whose symptoms could be alleviated. Women with advanced breast cancer are able to get a drug. But, no, you do not bother telling the people about that. You do not bother telling them that those measures have benefited some people with profound disease and disability as a result of that disease. No, you did not tell them that.
You put out a nasty and misleading pamphlet which Labor MPs and candidates were encouraged distribute to their electorates. The claim was made:

Under Mr Howard's plan wealthy people will be able to afford the newest, safest and most effective drugs but battling Australians will be forced to make do with the cheaper, less effective and less safe drugs.

Wrong, wrong, wrong; lie, lie, lie. That is what it was: an absolutely outrageous, disgraceful, scaremongering, lying campaign. What are the facts? The suggestion that the benchmark-priced drugs are less effective and less safe was made without one shred of evidence. Mr Lee has not had the good grace to come into the other House and apologise to all the older people he scared by saying that these drugs were less effective and less safe. He has continued to peddle this misinformation, and every single person who distributed one of those pamphlets deserves to be ashamed.

The government engaged independent medical experts to ensure that the medicines affected by the change had very similar clinical effects to others in the same group. The drugs are alike and work just as well as one another for the vast majority of people. A generous and broad exemption is available if people cannot change to a lower-priced drug for clinical reasons. The doctor can make that clinical decision, and those people will be exempt. The exemption is available if the doctor believes that prescribing an alternative drug would cause patient confusion. Was that in the pamphlet? No. So the Labor Party continues to peddle lie after lie, misrepresentation after misrepresentation, and they should be ashamed. The Australian public deserves better than that.

A letter was circulated by a candidate, purportingâpretendingâthat he is going to represent people in the House of Representatives and lying that we are going to abolish Medicare, lying about the nursing home policy and lying that we have closed down Medicare access in the electorate to the north of mine. I will not deign to name the electorate because I will not give him the credit of being recognised. Dr Wooldridge in the other place has rebutted those claimsâthose outrageous lies.

Labor has focused its campaign of fear and misinformation on the most vulnerable people in our community. The aged, the sick and struggling families have been the targets of Labor's misinformation campaign. Is it any wonder there is widespread cynicism in our community? Is it any wonder that Australians do not trust politicians? Is it any wonder that One Nation gets votes when Labor continues to behave in the way it does? The Australian people have a right to expect better than misinformation and misrepresentation from their elected representatives. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âToday I want to speak about salary packaging, tax minimisation and, frankly, tax avoidance strategies that are being pursued in the community. I recently saw the statement, `Make hay while the sun shines'. It was an accounting firm, Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu providing that advice on the website to those thinking about salary packaging. Quite frankly, it is more a question of `evade tax while the law is lax', because what we are seeing is an explosion of salary packaging in order to minimise the appropriate payment of taxation, largely by the wealthy but spreading through what would normally be considered middle income salary earners.

speech.para: Deloittes correctly conclude that recent tax changes appear to have sparked another wave of salary packaging. They are at pains to answer in the negative the question: is this all too good to be true? They are very keen to encourage people to take advantage of the loopholes in the existing law and the government's failure to apply pressure to ensure that people pay appropriate taxation, just as in the area of trusts law which has been the subject of great debate in this parliament over recent years. Salary packaging is another example of where the government has failed to act to avoid tax minimisation by wealthy individuals.

We are seeing an explosion of salary packaging not only in the private sector but also in the charitable sector and now in the public sector. The causes include the recent tax changes such as the super surcharge, or tax, and the additional Medicare levy. But they also include the failure by the government to combat the growth in salary packaging for the purpose of tax avoidance.

The government, contrary to some of its rhetoric, is even encouraging excessive salary packaging within its own government departments. We now see evidence that the government is encouraging individuals in its own employ to salary package up to 50 per cent of their salary in non-cash benefits for no purpose other than the minimisation of taxation. There is no legitimate reason that can justify 50 per cent of salary being taken in non-cash benefits. I know that a lot of people view tax minimisation as a legitimate taxation strategy, and I think to a certain extent the community accepts that, but not when it is pursued in the form and the manner in which it is being pursued in the community currently.

Serious problems are being caused by the explosion of salary packaging and the resulting tax minimisation and avoidance. The first is revenue loss. By people packaging their salaries and avoiding paying income tax on that component of their salary, considerable income tax is forfeited to the Commonwealth. That reduces our ability to provide services such as child care and health care to the community. It is hard to get a hold on how much is being lost in this way, but in 1995 the Industry Commission estimated that if salary packaging became widespread just within the public benevolent institutionsâthe charitable areaâthe loss of revenue would be approximately $200 million each year. In one small sector of the economy, the Industry Commission estimated that the sort of development that has since taken place in terms of the explosion of salary packaging could lose the government $200 million of revenue per annum.

If we look at what has happened in the much larger private sector in recent years and the explosion that has taken place since the government's super surcharge and Medicare levy, and at what is now developing in both the state and federal government areas, we find that this is a major drain on revenue and a major problem for our community. We complain about the standard of our schools, the lack of child care and the inability to get operations in public hospitals, but this is partly caused by the reduction in government revenue as a result of the minimisation strat egies being pursued as part of salary packaging.

The other impacts of salary packaging include people now being able to access family payments. People lower their total taxable income by taking part of their salary in non-cash benefits and that allows them to access things such as family payments. Executives who would have been on $80,000 per annum, with two children and a non-working spouse, could, by packaging their salary, reduce their accessible income to $60,000 and, as a result, qualify for a family allowance payment of $47 per fortnight. By reducing and packaging their salary, they have a net benefit of not only lower tax but also government assistance to which they would not normally be entitled.

A problem is also developing in the child support area where children are living in poverty when the non-custodial parent is able to reduce his or her taxable income. I know the major focus on this has been in the area of trusts and businesses, but salary packaging is beginning to become a real problem in terms of the child support payment system. The Australian Taxation Office has identified salary packaging as a serious threat to child support payments. That is another area where there ought to be a great deal of public concern.

The other question is one of equity. The essence of salary packaging is to allow wealthier individuals to be treated as if they are poorer than they really are for the purposes of assessing the tax they pay. This creates inequalities between people at different income levels. Rather than having a progressive tax system where the rich pay more, they are able to pay less as a result of this device. That is inequitable. It undermines our taxation system and it causes frustration among those who properly pay the appropriate level of tax. Traditionally, this has been available only to very high income earners. We think of salary packaging applying to private company executives, but it is spreading throughout the communityâin the public, private and charitable sectors.

The government seems unwilling, or unable, to deal with the issue. It does, however, recognise that there is a problem. The mid-year economic and fiscal outlook for 1997-98 identifies the evasion of the super surcharge through salary packaging as a specific risk to revenue. It states:

Because the income levels are largely based on taxable income, there is a risk to revenue if otherwise high income earners enter into salary packaging arrangements to reduce the amount of their taxable income (but with no net impact on their total remuneration). The risk of such arrangements becoming widespread is likely to increase in 1997-98 . . .

Even the government, in its mid-year economic outlook, recognises the problem in relation to superannuation. On top of that, there is the Medicare surcharge for high income earners and the range of developments that are occurring in relation to salary packaging in the community. In his booklet, The Australian taxation systemâin need of reform , the Treasurer (Mr Costello) proclaimed:
A rapidly expanding tax minimising strategy involves salary sacrificingâtaking a portion of salary in the form of fringe benefits.
He described it as `rapidly expanding' and went on to say:
For example, by taking salary of $70,000 in non-salary fringe benefits, a high income earner can avoid the superannuation surcharge and access some government benefits.

So the Treasurer acknowledges that, firstly, the system is rapidly expanding; secondly, people are avoiding tax; and, thirdly, people are getting access to social security benefits designed for those in need. But what does the government do about it? It accepts that there is a problem but does nothing about it. It offers no solution. The only action that is taken is that Mr Costello offers the observation that, when taxes are high, people try harder to avoid tax: therefore, the answer to that is to lower their tax. I think there is an alternative approach. We ought to be concerned with the equity involved. We ought not just concede that high income earners are able to avoid tax and that if we tax them more they are encouraged to find minimisation strategies. We should not just say, `That is the way of the world.' I would have thought we should say that they should pay their fair share of tax. We have to take action to make sure that happens.

The Labor Party thinks there are alternatives. We do think we can crack down on tax avoidance by the wealthy. We do think we can ensure that they pay their fair share of tax. We certainly think they should not be encouraged and allowed to access family payments and other social security measures that are designed for those people in needâthose raising children who are struggling to make ends meet. It is just not good enough to say, `It's all too hard. Maybe we ought to impose a GST on everybodyâthat way we will raise some money from a broad-based consumption taxâand give up on trying to make the wealthy pay their proper level of tax.' That is not acceptable. Certainly, the government should not be looking to encourage excessive salary packaging among its own employees.

We are now seeing the growth of salary packaging and tax minimisation in the public sector, without any realisation, it seems to me, that the source of those departments' income is revenue raised from the very people that they are now assisting to avoid paying tax. We see agreements being struck in the public sector where Public Service executives can package up to 50 per cent of their income in non-salary measures, such as superannuation, cars, hospital insurance benefits and God knows what else. The workplace relations and veterans' affairs departments allow 50 per cent of salary to be packaged in that way, thereby allowing tax minimisation and tax avoidance on up to 50 per cent of the income of the people employed by those departments. I do not think that is acceptable.

The tax commissioner has taken a quite different view. Mr Carmody has said that, from the tax office's point of view, they will not be encouraging this tax aggressive measure. I gather that they frown on anything in the private sector that exceeds 30 per cent. I have been told informally that to charities and others theyâthe tax officeâsay that anything above 30 per cent salary packaging will incur close scrutiny by them. But their own fellow Public Service departments are encouraging salary packaging by up to 50 per cent. That is a disgrace. The government ought to take a serious look at what is being allowed to occur under its own auspices.

The only defence the government offersâand the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) did this in the House in answer to a questionâis to say that the public sector ought to be treated like the private sector. So if the private sector are allowed salary packaging and tax avoidance, salary packaging and tax avoidance should be allowed in the public sector. What nonsense! If something is wrong we ought to fix it, not encourage the flow on to public servants. The tax commissioner, as I say, took a very different view. In a memo to staff he said:

. . . I believe it would be inappropriate for us, as the organisation with a pivotal role in supporting the integrity of Australia's tax and child support system, to aggressively take up the option of salary packaging.

In contrast to his strong leadership, the government vacillates on the issue. Mr Carmody did not think it appropriate for the tax office in dealing with its own employees to pursue the tax minimisation strategy that other departments are following. The best the other Commonwealth departments can do is to ask employees to sign a declaration, which is really quite cute. They encourage people to avoid tax on up to 50 per cent of their salary by taking these packaging measures, but then they ask them to sign a declaration which says:

For ethical reasons, employees will sign a declaration that they will not access any Government provided benefit, such as Department of Social Security benefits or AUSTUDY, or adjust payments for child support, that would result solely through the reductions in gross salary from salary packaging.

If ever you have seen a system damned, there it is. They know there is an ethical problem and they know there is a tax minimisation and avoidance problem, so they ask employees to accept responsibility for not accessing those entitlements that this device allows them to access. It is a cop-out. It is unenforceable, and they know it is unenforceable. What they are doing is trying to provide some minor protection against the criticism that will flow of the departments and the government in allowing this tax minimisation strategy to flourish in government departments. There are all sorts of ethical problems with this approach. There are all sorts of revenue problems for the government with this approach.

We ought to be taking a far different approach to the problem of the excessive salary packaging that is occurring in the community. We ought to be setting limits and enforcing appropriate behaviour to ensure that only legitimate salary packaging occursânot the tax minimisation strategies that are flourishing in the private and public sectors at the moment. The government is, by this device, encouraging tax minimisation, encouraging accessing of social security benefits by those who would otherwise not be entitled to them, allowing people to escape child support payments, undermining its own super and Medicare surcharges and bringing the taxation system into disrepute. It must take steps to ensure that proper taxation is paid by individuals and it must support the continuation of equity in our taxation system.

talk.start.para: âI want to talk about the real problem in Australian politics at present. Explicitly, this concerns the organisation, function and structure of political parties. Political parties are less regulated than corporations, associations and unions. They are subject to little if any real control as to the propriety of their conduct and the fairness of their internal processes. If it is in the interest of some powerful figures within political parties to keep their wheeling and dealing behind closed doors, that is not a position universally supported by the members of political parties. And it is not in the public interest.

speech.para: The Democrats believe that reform is long overdue and that political parties must meet the ordinary standards of accountability and openness demanded of other vital institutions in our society. This is even more essential now that parties receive public funds to conduct their political campaigns. Everyone knows that politicians are on the nose. A Morgan poll of 21 May 1998 found that only seven per cent of Australians believe that members of both state and federal parliaments have high or very high standards of ethics and honesty. This has fallen from 20 per cent in the late 1970s.

The Morgan poll found that the only professionals rated lower than politicians were used car salesmen. That seven per cent rating for politicians is for people whose calling is supposedly to serve the public. On 3 May 1998, Channel 9's Sunday program produced a documentary on Labor Party branch stacking in Victoria. Whether or not that program got matters right, the effect was the same. It reinforced the public perception of party politics as corrupt, dishonest, venal, immoral and unprincipled.

Perhaps the most outstanding recent example of the way in which political parties can be a law unto themselves is the new Pauline Hanson One Nation Party. As we learn each day from disenchanted former supporters, this political party appears to have all the hallmarks of a political dictatorship. Its eliteâDavid Oldfield, David Ettridge and Pauline Hansonâhas used the attraction of its being a grassroots organisation made up of ordinary Australians as a key part of its rhetoric and political strategy, and yet it seems apparent from what has been said by observers and commentators that the two Davids and, to a lesser extent, Pauline, as sole directors and executives of a public, non-listed, limited liability company, have complete control over the party. That is not grassroots: that is dictatorship.

Contrast this with the set-up of my own party, the Australian Democrats. The Australian Democrats also claim to be a party of the grassroots. With us, every crucial decision in terms of policy, every preselection and every leadership contest must be made by the membership via ballot. I do not want to claim excessive virtue for my party, but it does abhor, reject and constitutionally prohibit the kind of shady backroom factional balloting that political parties are notorious for. The Australian Democrats believe in a fully open and accountable process that genuinely involves the full membership.

One Nation, a party that could in the future be represented in this chamber, will, like all political parties, be less regulated than the local tennis club. If it were not for the recent revelations in the media, its members, the public, and this parliament would not even have been aware in the upcoming election of the true nature of this organisation. Let me give you someone else's assessment of that party.

That someone else is Barbara Hazelton, Pauline Hanson's former personal secretary. In the Australian yesterday, 30 June, Barbara Hazelton wrote what appeared to be an honest account of her experiences with One Nation. In the article, she described herself as a `heartbroken supporter', and reading it, I think she really meant it. I will quote selected passages from what is a very long and very revealing article. Barbara Hazelton said:
What needs to be exposed is David Oldfield's One Nation.
Oldfield is a manipulative, hypnotic, hugely narcissistic individual . . .
Literally hundreds of people have contacted the office complaining about mismanagement by the One Nation head office in Manly.
. . .. many had not received a receipt for their $500 donation.
Talking of Pauline Hanson, Barbara Hazelton says:

. . . she was working out with Helen and me how to get rid of them (the two Davids)âbut she was concerned about an agreement she'd made. I didn't then know anything about such an agreement but subsequently read about the "secret pact"â
it sounds like Germany and Russiaâ
- which I assume is the One Nation corporate structureâbinding the three of them together. She seemed very puzzled/worried that she could not find her copy of the agreement.
Hazelton continues:

A few weeks ago, members of the relevant committee wanted to declare all positions in One Nation vacant and have a democratic election to fill them. They then found out that this was impossible because of One Nation's corporate structure. At present, solicitors are being consulted to investigate ways whereby Pauline could remove the two Davidsâunder the company structureâbut my feeling is that Pauline needs to be careful lest she find herself beyond being able to take any action to rein in the two Davids no matter how good the intentions of the people trying to help her by doing this.
Further on, Barbara Hazelton says:
My biggest single worry about Oldfield is that he holds the ordinary people who support Pauline in contempt.
And this is from someone who knows him intimately. She continues:

The week before the election, I asked Heather Hill (the Queensland leader of One Nation) why, in her launch speech, she had said we weren't directing preferences. She replied: "Because we aren't." I told her, "yes, we are", and suggested she contact Oldfield about it. When she got off the phone, she said words to the effect that Oldfield had said that "yes, we were distributing preferences in a handful of seats, maybe six or eight."
I do not know about you, but I only have five fingers on my hand! Hazelton went on to say:
I knew that cards had been reprinted distributing preferences in many more seats. Oldfield couldn't even tell the truth to the Queensland leader of One Nation.
It is interesting that she says `the Queensland leader' and not `the national leader'. The article continues:
Pauline used to say that if she ever lost control she would resign. She knows she's no longer in control . . .
Those are not my words. I have quoted extensively from an article written by Pauline Hanson's former personal secretary, Barbara Hazelton.

Obviously, it is not possible to fix all the problems of political parties and politicians that concern us but, through better regulation, you can install greater democracy in political parties, better standards of governance, better accountability and better safeguards against parties which might be run by a political dictatorship or elite. The experience the legislature has with corporations law, workplace relations law and associations lawâall of which cover the functions and structure of organisationsâconcerning the regulation of organisations and the standards required of them and their office-bearers, gives us a useful starting point.

Increased regulation of political parties is not inconsistent with the essential freedom of expression and freedom from unjustified state interference, influence or control. Greater regulation would offer political parties better protection from malpractice and corruption, and it would reduce the opportunity for the use of public funds for improper purposes.

The Commonwealth Electoral Act registers political parties and sets out minimal requirements for their registration. Formal public scrutiny of political parties commenced with the public disclosure of donations in 1984. The introduction of federal public funding of political parties based on votes received led to the requirement for the registration of political parties, as well as their legal recognition at the Commonwealth level. I would suggest that those areas of registration regulation are minimal and not maximal. The internal rules and procedures of political parties remain largely self-regulated, except where the act imposes certain requirements.

Arguments that political parties are private institutions and should not be subject to regulation are fallacious for three principal reasons. Firstly, political parties are now publicly funded, and that requires accountability to the public. The public has a right to know the ways in which political parties receive and spend public funds. Secondly, political parties are extensively and intimately involved in public life in every way. In particular, political parties are capable of exercising enormous power that affects all Australians. In government, they may even lead us into war. The public influence and purpose of political parties therefore demands that they be open to scrutiny, be publicly accountable and be run to the highest standards.

Thirdly, arguments that political parties are private institutions do not justify their freedom from regulation. In comparison with a public listed company or a private limited company in the private sector, the regulations and requirements placed on political parties are negligible. There are common standards of governance and public interest requirements for companies that should be at least equally applicable to political parties.

The Australian Democrats believe that political parties and organisations cannot be treated as purely private bodies. Because of the huge impact such organisations have on public life and on the fortunes of the nation, it is in the public interest that they perform under special financial disclosure regulations, as they mostly do at present, to help create a corruption free and honest political system. However, existing income and expenditure disclosure deals with only half the problem. The same principles of transparency and accountability should apply to ensure that political parties will behave in the manner in which their members under their constitutions say they will act.

In that regard, electoral legislation should draw on the Corporations Law. The most relevant aspects of the Corporations Law for political parties are: firstly, the procedural aspects which underlie the participatory nature of corporate affairs to see that they operate democratically in the organisational sense; and, secondly, oversight by a regulatory authority. Further legislative regulation of political parties is desirable in the areas of internal party organisation and procedures, the relationship between the party machine and its membership, and the preselection of candidates.

The Commonwealth Electoral Act could include a limited list of principles and items to be included in a political party's constitution, together with a requirement for party constitutions to be approved by the Australian Electoral Commission as a condition of registration. I can assure you, Madam Acting Deputy President, that the commission would not accept an elite of three controlling an organisation. The key constitutional principles might include: the what, who and how of membership; how office-bearers are preselected and elected; how preselection of political candidates is to be conducted; what processes exist for dispute resolution; and what processes exist for changing the constitution.

The Australian Electoral Commission should be empowered to receive and investigate complaints of breaches of a political party's constitution, but obviously only after the full internal processes of the party have been exhausted, otherwiseâas with every organisation: unions, companies or othersâit would do nothing else. Obviously, the AEC would not be empowered to act as a court, but it could have dispute resolution procedures. The AEC's main aim would be to encourage much better self-regulation and management by the membership and its office-bearers.

The relationship between the party machine and the party membership requires better and more standard regulatory, constitutional and select systems and procedures, which would enhance the relationship between the party hierarchy, office-bearers, employees, political representatives and the members. Greater regulation and scrutiny of political parties' preselections by the AEC would enhance fairness, transparency and legitimacy in the eyes of the public and members of political parties.

The current system of preselection by Australian political parties is discredited. The advantages of greater scrutiny by the Electoral Commission would be that including the commission in some way in the preselection process would help secure an authentic and unchallenged ballot. If external independent scrutiny is desirable, the preselection ballot could be run by the Australian Electoral Commission rather than by the controlling party elite or faction.

The Electoral Commission could conduct the count, which would increase transparency and ensure fairness through the use of a neutral umpire. It would also mean that parties could use fairer voting systems. In this way, the public could be reassured that preselection was not some private, corrupt, dishonest and rigged intra-party affair and that the successful candidate got up fairly.

In noting that some of the regulation appropriate for companies is similarly appropriate for political parties, I note that some of the protections are too. Like many companies, political parties guard some of their internal processes and information zealously because politics is a highly competitive activity. The competitive edge each party feels it has is vital to it. Legislation that provides for sufficient transparency and good process, without affecting a political party's ability to retain confidentiality where essential, can be achieved. Like the present disclosure regulation, any further regulation would need to be equally applicable to all.

subdebateinfo.title: Education: New South Wales Schools Funding

talk.start.para: âToday I want to comment on a matter of public importance, and that is the issue of funding for eduction in New South Wales. The New South Wales Teachers Federation, with the backing of its mates in the Carr government, has recently embarked on a campaign of misinformation over Commonwealth funding of schools in New South Wales. Part of this campaign was a totally irresponsible strike that left 800,000 students without adequate supervision at schools throughout the state. It also caused anguish and angst for parents who suddenly found they had to stay at home and mind their children when they needed to go to work. Needless to say, employers were not amused.

speech.para: But, rather than condemning what can only be described as a blatantly political exercise and an excuse to attack the Howard government, Bob Carr and his team hopped onto the bandwagon. The Carr government used the strike, predictably, as a vehicle for some more Canberra bashing. The teachers called the strike to protest against what they claimed was an increase in spending on private schools at the expense of public schools. The reality is that the shortfalls in funding for government schools in New South Wales have been caused by Bob Carr's failure to match the Commonwealth's commitment to the government school sector. The Commonwealth has, in fact, increased its funding to the New South Wales government for the government school sector by 7.4 per cent. This compares with the Carr government's paltry increase of 3.4 per centâand that is for its global schools budget.

The facts speak for themselves. Government schools in New South Wales will receive $520 million in direct Commonwealth funding this year, and this compares with federal Labor's last year in office when $471.7 million was provided in direct funding. That is almost $50 million more than New South Wales government schools received from Labor. On average, Commonwealth funding from all sources for a government school student this year is $2,144 a studentâup $157 a student on Labor's last year.
But the Teachers Federation is not really interested in the facts. As the Sydney Morning Herald editorial on the day after the strike put it:
It is hard to imagine a more transparent political stunt than yesterday's stopwork meeting by teachers in NSW government schools.
The editorial went on to say:
. . . yesterday's stopwork will achieve nothing for the public school sector.

But, of course, the Teachers Federation is a political body with very little real interest in education, I am sad to say. In its printed 16 objectives, only one deals with education. The rest deal with superannuation, wages, conditions and nuclear disarmament. Yes, you heard correctly. Can you really believe this? Nuclear disarmament is the union's eleventh objective and it sits next to its tenth objective which is, in fact, education. Perhaps we should be grateful that education cracks a mention at all. Nuclear disarmament is no doubt important and a worthy issue but one that hardly fits into the role of teachers who perhaps should be more interested in the students they teach, what they teach, how they teach and, heavens above, what outcomes they can achieve.

Mind you, this is the same union that so far has opposed literacy standards, opposes proper reporting to parents, prevents and opposes proactively helping school leavers get a job and has deep-seated opposition to the right of parents to choose the school which best suits their child. This is the union that, during the recent strike action, made the totally false and fatuous claim that 42 non-government schools were receiving the same amount of federal government funding as 478 government schools. To arrive at this mischievous and misleading claim, the union compared the funding for government schools from one specific government programâin fact, it was formerly the disadvantaged schools program and is now absorbed into the overall literacy programâwith total funding for non-government schools.

Put in terms which even the union might understand, it compared one fraction of the Commonwealth funding for government schools with the total funding that the federal government provides to these non-government schools. It is beyond the realms of imagination to believe that the Carr government was not aware of the truth about the level of Commonwealth funding. But, in its usual manner, it decided to twist the truth and to try to hide its own maladministration of funds for the school sectors. The Sydney Morning Herald editorial, to which I referred a little earlier, stated that the reason schools in New South Wales were under stress and morale was low was:
. . . more to do with state government policies than federal policies.
Further on, the editorial highlighted the deceitful stance of the Carr government and stated:
The Premier, Mr Carr, is happy for teachers to believe that the blame should be sheeted home to Canberraâor even on to the private school sector.

I suppose it is understandable. Mr Carr is desperate because he sees his premiership slipping away from him at the next election. The voters will not be fooled about funding and the excuses are finally being seen through. It is therefore an opportune time, given Bob Carr's support for the Teachers Federation tacticsâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! I ask you to address the Premier of New South Wales by his correct title. It is Premier Carr.

âPremier Carr. It is therefore an opportune time, given Premier Carr's support for the Teachers Federation tactic, to examine education funding. The facts are: the Commonwealth has increased its funding by 7.4 per cent to the New South Wales state government for the government school sector; the state government has major responsibility for this sector; and the Carr government has increased global schools budget by 3.4 per centâand this figure includes the Commonwealth growth funds.

speech.para: As I stated before, government schools in New South Wales will receive $520 million in direct Commonwealth funds, nearly $50 million more than they were allocated in federal Labor's last year. Per capita spending is now $2,144âup $157 on the Labor government's last year. The high level of funding demands answers as to where all the money has gone. How has it been applied? It is the state government that decides the funding levels for government schools, not the federal government. It is all very well for Premier Carr and his education minister, John Aquilina, to point fingers at the federal government, but it is they who actually decide what schools get what funds.

If the Teachers Federation was really concerned about the government school system, it would be asking Premier Carr and Mr Aquilina some pretty tough questions. But the truth is that the Carr government and the union have simply hopped into bed together on this issue. Under the sheets their motto is more `Let's get political' than `Let's get physical.' But what they have to realise is that the Howard government is committed to government school education as well as non-government school education. The Teachers Federation should be asking the Carr government where the money made available for government schools has actually gone.

The union and the Carr government also handily forget about the range of initiatives taken under the coalition government for schools across Australia. These programs directly benefit New South Wales and include: increased funding of $45 million over four years for literacy and numeracy in schools; cooperative development of literacy and numeracy benchmarks to identify students most in need of help; funding of $187 million over four years to support vocational education in schools and to promote effective and reliable pathways from school actually into employment; $44 million over three years for initiatives to help students returning to school in response to the youth allowance and for existing students at risk of leaving school prematurely; a clear commitment to ensuring educational justice for indigenous Australians from preschool to university through funding of $333.8 million in 1998-99 for indigenous education; a $17.5 million `Discovering Democracy' civics and citizenship program providing free materials to all schools; a $7.5 million school drugs strategy to provide a national framework for the delivery of drug education in schools; an additional $42.6 million for the national Asian languages and studies in Australian schools strategy, which aims to help young people learn Asian languages; and $163 million for targeted programs to help students with special learning needs, including rural and isolated studentsâthe kids in the bush who always miss outâand new arrivals in need of `English as a second language' tuition and assistance for disabled students.

But it would be asking a bit too much of the Carr government and the union to remember all these initiatives in the never-ending quest to try to blame anyone but that government for its own inadequacies. One of the great bungles from the Carr government bunker has been the much-vaunted $50 back to school allowance which has been paid to some families. Others have been overlooked, and some have been overpaid. The list of reported bungles in this one area is impressively woeful: delays of months for payment of the allowance; one family spent what they budgeted for from the allowance but, although the cheque was apparently posted, it did not turn up; a family with three children received $350 instead of $150; parents of HSC students doing TAFE courses through the HSC pathways program did not receive the $50 allowance; and some parents cashed their cheques at local pubs.

The Carr government's appalling record is, of course, worthy of note. But, rather than rectifying the problems that this government has foisted upon the people of New South Wales, Premier Carr has formed an alliance with the Teachers Federation. What has become very apparent from the Teachers Federation tactics is that one of the items on its agenda is that it seeks to unravel the system of two competitive school sectors. It does not want a non-government school sector and, by trying to destroy faith in the government school system, it aims to bring pressure to scrap the non-government system and boost the government system.

But the coalition government is committed to the development and maintenance of two strong and competitive school sectors that maximise the choices available to both students and parents. When the union claims that the Commonwealth has restricted funding to the government sector in favour of the non-government sector, it is simply distorting the facts. But what it does not realise, or does not want to realise, is that, when a student moves from a government to a non-government school, the state government makes a saving and the Commonwealth pays more. Under the enrolment benchmark adjustment scheme, the state government is required to return to the Commonwealth half the savings that accrue when the proportion of students in non-government schools increases against the 1996 enrolment benchmark.
Explaining the system, the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, Senator Ellison, wrote in the Australian newspaper on 4 May this year:

The EBA is calculated at the end of each year following a student census to determine the actual drift in enrolments in a State compared to 1996. The calculation involves using actual average expenditure by a State on students in government and non-government schools. If the census shows no change in relative enrolment shares, or an increase in the government share, the EBA is not triggered.

So the NSW government helped, of course, to establish the system and actually profits from students switching to non-government schools. But, again, the question that remains unanswered is: where does all the money go?

Rather than pursue this legitimate exercise in accountability, the union has simply now joined the Labor Party in a blatant attempt to damage and talk down government schools and the faith of parents in government schools. It is seeking to erode public support for government schooling by embarking on a misleading campaign. But it will not succeed. The coalition government will continue to fight for quality education for all Australian children. It will defend the right of parents, particularly low income parents, to choose their own schoolsâschools that suit the needs of their own children.

This government will not be deterred by campaigns to mislead waged by the union and its Labor mates. Those very campaigns will haunt the Premier at the next election, because so many people now see these excuses for what they areâdamning evidence of yet another way in which the Carr government is failing the people of New South Wales.

talk.start.para: âI rise to draw the attention of the Australian public to the fact that today, 1 July, is one of the blackest days in the history of this country for Australian workers. This morning, many thousands of Australian workers would have gone to their place of employment not knowing that their conditions of employment had changedâthat many of the conditions they thought were enshrined in their awards and were there as a right had been abolished as a result of the actions of this government, and that in fact they were now open to exploitation by their employer.

speech.para: These changes are as a direct result of legislation introduced by this government over the period of the past two years as part of this government's approach to the issue of industrial relations. It is again a very clear demonstration of the difference between the promises made by Prime Minister Howard prior to the 1996 election and the outcomes that we have received from the Howard coalition government. What did Mr Howard say in 1995? On 6 October 1995 he said:
No worker in Australia under the Howard industrial relations system can have his or her award conditions taken from him or her.
That was a cast-iron guarantee. He went on to say on 8 January 1996:
Under a Howard government you cannot be worse off.
That was a bit like his commitment on the GST: `Never ever, until I get the opportunity to put the boot into you.'

He did not only con Australian workers before the last election. He actually conned a lot of the journalists around this country, because the industrial editor of the Sydney Morning Herald in an article on 23 February 1996 observed:
John Howard has very successfully neutralised the brunt of a planned Labor scare campaignâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! Senator Campbell, it is not appropriate to call the Prime Minister John Howard.
âI am quoting from a Sydney Morning Herald article.

âI have been advised by the clerk that you cannot say anything in a quote that you are not permitted to say in the Senate. It would be appropriate to rephrase that to `And they addressed him as Prime Minister John Howard.'
âI find it difficult to know how I can quote the exact article out of the Sydney Morning Herald without changing it.
âI am sure you have got the creative ability to do that.
âThe industrial editor of the Sydney Morning Herald in an article on 23 February 1996 observed that the Prime Minister:

speech.para: John Howardâ
who was then opposition leaderâ

has very successfully neutralised the brunt of a planned Labor scare campaign by giving `a rock solid guarantee' that his policy will not result in a cut in the take home pay of Australian workers. By this he means that the present system of awards that set out in great detail the minimum wages and conditions of workers will remain intact.
It just goes to prove that, if you tell a good enough lie, even the experts will believe you.

The reality is that, when you look at and examine carefully the actions of this government, you have to clearly distinguish between the rhetoric that they use in terms of addressing the Australian public and the outcomes that they actually put into practice. The reality is that the actions of this government and the impact of those changes that apply from today, 1 July, will in fact attack the most vulnerable in our society. The most vulnerable in our society are the ones who will pay the greatest penalty as a result of these changes.

talk.start.para: âParticularly women.

âAs Senator Mackay says, particularly women in the work force. But that is not enough for some. Mr Stan Wallis, the head of the Business Council of Australia, is quoted in the newspapers today as saying, `Labour reform has not gone far enough. We have to take it further if we are going to be able to compete in the rough and tumble of the global economy. We need more labour reform.' Labour reform, in his words, means a reduction in workers' living standards.

speech.para: It is a very sad day in many respects that, after 90 years of history of a conciliation and arbitration system in this country which has underpinned the living standards of the Australian community, we have now seen the introduction and application of a decision by a government that has reversed the positive and progressive trend that has occurred out of decisions of the commission over 90 yearsâstarting with the 1905 harvester decision, the 1956 boilermakers case, the 1969 total wage case, the 1974 wage indexation changes, the 1986 superannuation decision and the 1992 decision to introduce enterprise bargaining and to underpin that bargaining with the award system as a safety net for all workers. Now, in 1998, we see that whole process of progressive change on behalf of Australian workers being turned on its head. We have had a journey of some 90 years, and we have now seen a conservative government take the first steps to neutralise a system that has underpinned the living standards of Australians over that whole period of time. They have now used the legislative processes to cut back on the living standards of workers.

I suppose the greatest tragedy in all of this is that the groups that are targeted include the people who will best be protected in the process. The reality is that the unionised work force in this country will hardly be impacted by the changes that have been introduced today, because those workers operating as a collective will ensure that their living standards are not impacted by this type of decision. They will be able to sustain those conditions that have now been wiped out as a result of the award stripping exercise through their process of enterprise bargaining and collective agreements. But the real tragedy is that the groups in this society who will be most impacted by these changes are the groups that the award system in fact was built up to protectâthat is, workers in regional and rural Australia who in the main are employed under the award structure, whose living standards are determined by what is in their awards.

We have recently been travelling around the country on an inquiry into regional unemployment, and it was said to us in a number of areas that some companies have had difficulty getting workers because the award rates of pay in the area are not much above what is available through the welfare system when you add in the cost that those workers have to endure in terms of travelling to and from work, et cetera. That is a very clear demonstration that the vast bulk of workers in regional and rural Australia rely on the award system to underpin their living standards. That no longer is the case. We will see over the forthcoming months many examples emerge where workers in this country will start to become exploited by their employers, now that the underpinning of their conditions have been removed.

As I said, the union work force will not be impacted. As the MUA dispute clearly demonstrated, the unions have a capacity to maintain their position and to do it well. If there was one comment that came out of the dispute on the waterfront which I think was pretty telling, it was the comment of one of the employees coming out of the gates of Webb Dock after he had been given the bullet by PCS. He said to a television reporter, `One of the lessons I've learnt in this dispute is you've got to get yourself a strong union to look after your interests.' This was from a person who was engaged to go through the process of union busting on the waterfront.

However, the reality is that the other group of workers in this community who are going to be severely impacted by these changes is non-union labour: the very people the government encouraged to get out of unions and the union movement, the very people the government told, `We will protect you. Prime Minister John Howard will protect you. We will give you a rock solid guarantee that your conditions of employment will not be touched.' They are the ones who will be exploited the most by these changes. They are the ones who are the most vulnerable in the process and they are the ones who will have little opportunity to defend themselves when employers start to strip away the benefits of those conditions that were in those awards that applied to them.

There is an upside to all of this of course, because what will also happen, as happened with the MUA dispute, is that workers will come knocking on the doors of the trade union movement saying, `We want to join. We now understand what unions are there for. More importantly, we understand that, if our living standards are going to be protected, we can only do it through collective organisations, through trade unions.' The same message that many thousands of workers in this country got through the MUA dispute, they will get through the process of what is occurring with the award stripping exercise today.

I also want to say to those workers that they should not take any comfort from the fact that their position may be protected or resolved by the policies of One Nation, because the leader of that sordid group supported the Workplace Relations Act introduced by this government. She voted for it. So her philosophy, her principle, is consistent with that of this government.

I just want to say in the few minutes that are remaining to me that workers should not despair because the Labor Party has got a plan to restore those entitlements to you. We have a 10-point plan, but it is a positive 10-point plan. It is about restoring to workers those rights that underpin the living standards of every worker in this country.

What are the 10 points that the next Labor government will put in place? They are very clear and simple commitments. We will fix up the award system and we will restore the AIRC. We will make awards effective and we will make them comprehensive. We will give all employees access to the federal award system. We will make the system of bargaining fairer. We will ensure that employees are no worse off. We will give priority to collective bargaining, but collective bargaining underpinned by a comprehensive award system. We will abolish the Office of the Employment Advocate. We will provide an effective right of entry for unions to protect the interests of workers. We will put an emphasis on the resolution of industrial disputesânot the creation of industrial disputes, as has been the record of this government. We will not go out to create disputes on the waterfront; we will go out to resolve those disputes. A Labor government will take the necessary steps to protect the interests of every worker in this country.
Government senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âI can understand the interjections from the other side, because they know that they conned the Australian workers in 1996. But the reality is that, in 1998, they will not con the Australian workers a second time.

âMy question is to Senator Vanstone representing the Attorney-General. Can the minister confirm that there are at least four agencies within the Attorney-General's portfolio with vacant office space on leases ranging up to 2007? Is the minister aware that the Human Rights Commission has vacated 1,200 square metres in central Sydney but remains liable to pay $2.71 million until expiry of the lease in 2004; or that the Australian Government Solicitor remains liable to pay $5.65 million until 2002 in the Sydney CBD, $471,000 until 2002 in Darwin, $1.34 million until 2006 in Adelaide's CBD, and $1.52 million until 2007 in the Melbourne CBD; or that the Australian Protective Service remains liable to pay $481,000 until 1999 on a property in Kingston ACT; or that the Federal Court remains liable for vacated Industrial Relations Court premises in Sydney at a cost of $83,000?
âTime, time!
âOrder, Senator! The time for asking the question has terminated.
âShe had to wait for the minister to come in.
âI call Senator Vanston to answer the question.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Justice

talk.start.para: âI thank the senator for her question. She has obviously done a significant amount of research to prepare that question. She nods in appreciation. I hope she is nodding truthfully, and has not simply accepted work someone else has done on her behalf. If she has done that work, then good luck go to her. It would not be a surprise to you, Madam President, to know that I do not have a brief on the vacant space through the Attorney-General's Department, as I am confident a number of other ministers would not have, but I will seek some advice for the senator in regard to that matter and get back to her.

answer.para: What I can say is that I am absolutely confident that the Attorney-General's Department, along with all other departments, are managing their property servicesâto the extent they have control over themâas best as is possible. Sometimes as a consequence of policy changes, sometimes as a consequence of a change in size of an organisationâgoing up or down and needing different accommodationâthere can be vacant space in any organisation. The key requirement of course is to properly manage one's responsibilities and liabilities. The Commonwealth is no different from another lessee of space in that, when the space is no longer required, it cannot just walk away from a contract; it has to live up to its contractual obligations. That, of course, means managing one's property responsibilities as best one can. I am confident we are doing that. I am confident that this government would be doing it across the board far more efficiently and effectively than the previous government. As to the specifics, I will seek some information for the senator.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, given this projected waste of $12.255 million up to 2007, couldn't the government have better prioritised this expenditure to enhance legal aid or Family Court counselling? How can this gross waste of money on empty offices in this portfolio possibly be defended?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Justice

talk.start.para: âI regret that the senator was obviously not listening to the answer or perhaps does not understand the contractual arrangement that one might enter into when one leases property. Perhaps the senator thinks that the Commonwealth can be a bad renter or client in that respect and just walk away and not pay up. Perhaps the senator thinks that where there is vacant space that can be just turned into cash overnight and that the Commonwealth responsibilities can somehow be removed with a magic wand. The plain facts are that where the Commonwealth has entered into a contract it is liable under that contract. And, as with any other business that moves from one premises to another for whatever appropriate reasons, there may then be a vacant space not taken up that has to be paid for until it can be sub-let or alternative Commonwealth uses made of that space. Senator, for you to simplistically assume that you can take the cost of vacant space, turn it into cash and spend it on something else is naive in the extreme. (Time expired)

âMy question is to Senator Kemp. The coalition government's $3.9 billion savings rebate initiative starts today. For the first time, all Australians have the opportunity to benefit from a tax cut on their savings. Will the minister inform the Senate of the benefits of the rebate? Could he also outline the types of savings and investments that will be covered, and how many Australians are expected to receive the rebate?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: âThank you, Senator Abetz, for that important question and for drawing the attention of the Senate and the Australian public to the fact that this is the day on which the savings rebate commences. The savings rebate, as senators will recall, was a major initiative of the 1997 budget. It offers a significant tax break to people who earn income from their savings or investments, and will be a real incentive for Australians to save more. In my view, it is an important step in building Australia's savings culture. Many millions of Australians are expected to receive the savings rebate. In fact, all Australians have the opportunity to benefit.

answer.para: The rebate also rewards those who have already saved, particularlyâand I stress thatâself-funded retirees with income from privately funded pensions and annuities. I think that is a very important feature of the savings rebate. Of course, those people, you will remember, Madam President, would not have benefited under Labor's discredited so-called co-contribution scheme, which was tied up with Labor's broken promise on the l-a-w, law tax cuts.

talk.start.para: âYou broke your promise on that one.
âI am glad that Senator Sherry confirmed that Labor did break the l-a-w, law tax cuts. Thank you, Senator Sherry, for confirming what I said.
âNo, I am just reminding you that you have broken your promise.

âNow don't change your mind, Senator Sherry. The bulk of the rebate will flow to Australians with an annual income of less than $40,000. Taxpayers should start saving now to ensure they obtain the maximum rebate. Eligible taxpayers will be able to claim the rebate from today through the PAYE and provisional tax systems or on assessment at the end of the year. The rebate is designed to encourage private savings and to enhance Australia's retirement income system in a simple, fair and flexible way which allows individuals to choose the form of savings which is most suited to their needs.

answer.para: The savings rebate will work as follows from today: the first-year rebate of 7.5 per cent will apply to every dollar of saving or investment income or personal undeducted superannuation contributions, up to a maximum of $3,000; and the full rebate of 15 per cent will apply from 1 July 1999 to the $3,000 cap, thus providing a maximum rebate of $450 per person. For low and middle income earners, the first $1,000 of personal superannuation contributions will attract both the savings rebate and the existing 10 per cent rebate that is available to individuals earning up to $31,000. Unlike Labor's unworkable proposal which was to apply to super savings only, the savings rebate will be allowable on income from a wide range of savings and investments, such as interest on bank accounts and dividends from shares. This was a very important budget initiative which I believe was widely welcomed by Australians. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Taxation Office: Vacant Office Space

talk.start.para: âMy question is also addressed to the Assistant Treasurer. Can the minister confirm that the Australian Taxation Office expects to pay some $40 million in dead rent between two office buildings it has vacated in recent monthsânamely, Bankstown in Sydney and Cheltenham in Melbourneâwith leases still to run until 2002? Is the minister aware that these offices have not been vacated because the ATO has been downsized; but rather their staff have been transferred to other offices and, in the case of Cheltenham, some have been sent across Melbourne to Moonee Ponds? How can the government possibly justify this wasted rent money, these forced transfers and this removal of taxation offices from important business centres in Sydney and Melbourne? Is this not just another example of this government withdrawing Commonwealth services from the people who pay for them and wasting money at the same time?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: âThe Labor Party used to be regarded as a party of reformâindeed, some people like Senator George Campbell used to be regarded as radicalsâbut now, in many ways, we find that it is a party that hates change and resists change. Frankly, I would have thought that Senator Campbell would have recognised that times change. It is important that we have an efficient tax office which delivers best practice, and this does involve change. I am sorry, Senator Campbell, that you are a person who resists change.

answer.para: The ATO is looking to maintain accommodation in holdings in step with the ATO's changing business requirements. The benefits gained from these approaches will be used for additional staff and support for the improved operation of the tax system and will benefit the Australian community. The application of these approaches foreshadow that the existing site in Cheltenham, which you mentioned, will not be required in the medium term and that a reduced requirement will exist in Bankstown. Earliest dates for the subletting of these sitesâyou mentioned the issue of sublettingâwill be this June. It is a very important objective to ensure that the service to clients is maintained.

The ATO is examining and developing alternative means of meeting clients needs. While issues have been raised as to the impact on the local community and business, the plans are predicated on subleasing the offices in Cheltenham and Bankstown, thereby maintaining, through new tenants, the total numbers employed in these locations. On the staffing side, the plans will result in existing staff being placed in jobsâwherever possible in reasonable locations. There was consultation with groups on this proposal. As the tax office always does with proposed changes, it consults widely with staff and the unions as appropriate.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, given this utter waste of some $40 million on 19,800 square metres of vacant office space until two years into the next centuryâmoney which could have been put to much better use in the public health system, in child care or in public schoolsâhas the government imposed any similar political decisions on the tax office in relation to any other regional offices? If there are other examples, how much more taxpayers' money is being wasted by this government on dead rent?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: âSenator George Campbell does not seem to understand that we are in the business of creating a more efficient Taxation Office, which is what the Australian community expects. I am surprised that you, Senator Campbell, along with some of your colleagues resist making public services more efficient in this country, because that is essentially what you are trying to do. The Australian taxpayer is entitled to believe that the tax office and other government departments are operating at best practice. That, of course, is our intention.

âMy question is directed to Senator Warwick Parer, the popular Minister for Resources and Energy. My question relates to the alternative, simplistic economic prescriptions being promoted for the future of this country. Minister, what would be the impact on our resources industries, particularly our primary industries, on proposals that foreign investment be curtailed, Australia abandon job creating export opportunities, Australia return to a fixed exchange rate, and the belief that artificially low interest rate loans can be made available to select groups at the expense of others?

talker.name: Parer, Sen Warwick
Senator PARER
talker.role: Resources and Energy

talk.start.para: âI would like to thank Senator Watson for that question and for his compliments. It is important to remember just how much Australia relies on its primary and resource industries particularly when there are crazy proposals flying about, the bottom line of which would be to decimate those industries. There is a simple answer to all this political quackery: it would cost real jobs with rural and regional areas hit the hardest.

answer.para: Foreign investment provides us with many business and employment opportunities which would otherwise be lost, along with access to new technology and management skills. Our exports would decline such as our level of beef exports to Japan, influenced by Japanese investment in the beef industry, and there would also be no further sales of Mitsubishi cars to Japan. Our resources and primary industries are fully exposed to international competition and must therefore be truly internationally competitive. We should be very clear: if we reduce foreign investment in Australia, we will more than likely lose substantial sections of our domestic industries to other countries which are not flirting with anti-investment policies.

Abandoning trade liberalisation might appear to help primary industry, but, with three-quarters of our output being exported, the rural sector would be hit extremely hard. Stopping imports, for instance, of pork from Canada would jeopardise Australian exports to Canada which have a far greater value. We export eight times more primary products to Canada that we import. The damaging effect of abandoning trade liberalisation has been recognised recently in media statements by no less than the Cattle Council of Australia, the Wool Council of Australia, the Queensland Canegrowers Council and the Australian Dairy Industry Council, with the canegrowers noting that:
. . . attempts to limit the entry of foreign farmed products into Australia would have a massive detrimental effect on our great sugar industry.

Similarly, at a first glance, fixing the exchange rate to reduce volatility might seem to provide a buffer between Australia and the fortunes of other countries. In reality, it would make us more dependant on those countries, not less.

If the Australian dollar was tied to the US, fluctuations in the US would force the Reserve Bank to buy or sell large amounts of Australian dollars. We have all seen what happened to Asian countries which did exactly that. Providing artificially low exchange rates may also seem superficially attractive. The price, however, would be paid by small business and other rural industries. The bottom line of all these proposals is they could be counted in the loss of real jobs. They would reduce the attractiveness of Australia as a place to do business for both foreign investors and domestic business. The jobs impact would be worse in the rural and regional areas, the very areas which these policies are intended to protect.

The government established the market development task force to focus on bilateral trade activity, boosting the importance given to this by the previous Labor government. Successes include Australian banks in China, dairy products into Saudi Arabia and live cattle exports to China. This has created real jobs for Australian companies operating in Australia, real jobs in rural and regional areas instead of anti-investment policies which would cost jobs.

talk.start.para: âMy question is also to Senator Parer. It is now 111 days since the minister was exposed in a massive conflict of interest in relation to his shareholdings and 100 days since he made a statement in this place promising to divest himself ofâ
âOrder! Senator Parer is entitled to hear this question. I would ask people not to interject and shout, especially those near to him.

Will the minister now table those documents that prove he has actually divested himself of his interests in all relevant companies? Will the minister also table a statement on his revised shareholding arrangements in this chamber so that Australian people can be assured that he has genuinely divested himself of those shareholdings that gave rise to this conflict and not merely siphoned them off to entities in which he retains an indirect interest such as trusts or family members?

talker.name: Parer, Sen Warwick
Senator PARER

âOrder! It is important that the question be heard.

âWill you table in this chamber the documents that prove that you have divested yourself of a financial interest in companies that fall within your ministerial portfolio?
