talker.name: Parer, Sen Warwick
Senator PARER
talker.role: Resources and Energy

talk.start.para: âI have divested myself ofâ
âProve it; table the document.
âOrder! Senator Robert Ray, you have been persistently interjecting this afternoon.
âI have done everything that I have said I would do in accordance with the statement I made. I have nothing further to add.

âMy question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business. Minister, are you aware of calls by the Business Council of Australia for a new round of labour market changes, including reducing the safety net, introducing a savagely limited number of minimum conditions, stripping awards right back beyond the safety net, restricting the ability of unions to take industrial action even during bargaining periods, and stripping the Industrial Commission of most of its powers to solve disputes? Minister, does the government recognise that the act's changes to the award system are not complete and therefore calls for further major change are simply ambit claims? Will you confirm here that the government will continue to stand by its commitment that no worker will be made worse off as a result of any further changes planned by the coalition?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: âI do not claim to have come across that article. I do not know that Senator Murray was being specific when he talked about some business group, but it does not sound like a reasonable proposition to me. The approach that we have taken to the award process has certainly been much more concerned with simplification, and it could not be described as stripping. That is the sort of jargon you get from the other side, who are wholly owned subsidiaries of the trade union movement, because anything that affects their power base obviously affects their capacity to provide finds to the ALP at election time. So we are not surprised you get that sort of ongoing rhetoric from people, most of whom have not had real jobs.
âWhat sort of job have you had?

âI have been a member of the BLF, which is more than you can say. I know what it is like at the coalface. If you think real work is going around belting up defenceless party members and branch stacking, if that is what you think constitutes working for a living, that is pretty typical.
âSenator Alston, I draw your attention to the question.

âThe measures that we have taken to date provide not only adequate safety nets but also opportunities for all, particularly small businesses, to be able to negotiate in a transparent manner, not to be overwhelmed by all the minutia of award processes which have been used traditionally by the trade union movement as a means of binding hand and foot many small businesses who have been wanting to provide incentive and performance structures. We did certainly undertake that no worker would be worse off as a result of these changes. No-one has ever demonstrated that they areâin fact, quite the contrary.
âCome on!

âThe only people who might be are a few union organisers who have found that they have actually got to get out there and perform. I presume that because they spend most of their time preparing questions for you for estimates and all sorts of other helpful activities, you regard that as working for a living. Well, we do not. We think that people ought to be paid on per formance in terms of the wider community, not in terms of servicing interest groups like the ALPâone of the narrowest interest groups in the country, I might say, and one that has no interest or comprehension of what is happening out in rural areas.

answer.para: You are the ones running around with scare campaigns. You are the ones playing into the hands of Hanson. You are the ones who are not interested in policy reform. All you have done is ignore the real issues. We believe in proper workplace reform, and so does Senator Murray, and that is why he agreed with the approach we took. We were very grateful to Mrs Kernot at the time. I am sure she will not recant on that position she has taken. Even in her heart of hearts she must know that sensible workplace reform was well overdue in this country, and we have delivered in full.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, thank you for your answer. Do you agree that more than ever the safety net provided by awards, the vetting of agreements and oversight by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission are vitally important to protect the position of all Australian casual, part-time and full-time workers? Will you or the government be telling any extreme economic rationalists that might approach the government that the Workplace Relations Act still needs to settle down and that what is needed now is more attention to job security, not more attention to stripping the rights of employees?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: âI think it is generally correct to say that awards based on the new simplified approach do provide an adequate safety net. I certainly would not agree with what the other side would argue that all awards are the ultimate and only safety net and the more complicated they are the less ability there is to negotiate the better. We do not believe in any form of awards, but we do believe that the approach we have adopted, which provides for a minimum level of supporting critical areas but still provides flexibility, is the way to go.

answer.para: I very much appreciate Senator Murray's general support for the approach the government has adopted. I only hope that he will be out there exposing the inadequacies of the Labor Party in this area, showing that they are the troglodytes when it comes to reform in a whole range of areas. Their idea of security is to run around and tell people how insecure they ought to feel, to tell them that they have no hope, to tell them that only government can solve the problems, that people like Pauline Hanson, effectively, are saying what they believe. Well, it is not good enough, and it is about time you cleaned up your act. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âMy question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. What does the minister say to the Newcastle family who has just been told that their 18-year-old daughter will lose all of her unemployment benefit, her health care card and her public transport concessions due to the introduction of the youth allowance today? How does the minister explain to this family where one parent has a chronic illness and the other earns an average wage that they have to find an extra $87 a week to support their daughter? How does the minister explain to their daughter that she now has to pay an extra $39 for her asthma inhaler and pay full fare on the bus, not to mention the fees that job seekers who are not on social security now have to pay to get help with finding work?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Social Security

talk.start.para: âI have learnt enough in these years in politics to take claims like those I have just received from Senator Forshaw not at face value but subject to investigation. Having said that, and not, therefore, confirming the figures in his question at all by any means, I would say that people are starting now to get calls from Centrelink where their parental income is over the cut out level. Let me make it quite clear that that is the same cut out level that students will also be facing, and it is a much more generous cut out level than the Austudy parental means test, which was, of course, introduced and maintained for many years by Labor.

answer.para: It does depend on the family income. It depends on the number of children in the family. There is not enough information in your question to indicate just how well off that family is, just how many children there are. The circumstances are that no longer will young unemployed people have different entitlements from students of the same age and in the same family circumstances. No longer will we be paying more to young unemployed and less to students. They will have the same entitlements, but they will also all be parentally means test under the same parental means test. It is a more generous means test than you administered for many years on families for Austudy purposes. Let us be clear: if there is one young person in the family and they are living at home, the parental means test cuts out at just over $41,000.

talk.start.para: âIt starts cutting out at $23,400.

âWhich is your Austudy start, Senator, so do not give me any of that crying poor. It is intriguing that the people who would do nothing effective for young people in all those 13 years are now sitting wringing their hands on the sidelines. We are treating young people, regardless of their circumstances, better than Labor did because we have a more generous means test and we are treating brothers and sisters, unemployed or students, on the same basis.

answer.para: Students are now going to be more comfortably offâcomfortable, I suppose, is not the word, but they are certainly going to have better income support opportunities than they had under Labor. Young unemployed people will expect the same level of support from their parents as their brothers and sisters who are students. That is the rationale of it. It is a rationale which is accepted by Australian parents around the country who understand that it is not moral to be paying young people more to be unemployed than to be students. It sends a powerful message: it is a good thing to be a student, it is a good thing to improve your qualifications and, therefore, if you have the opportunity to do that, get out and do it, but do not come and say that young unemployed people should be treated more generously than Australian students.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. I point out, Minister, that you have not addressed any of the issues raised in the question. This is a real family. âExactly the point. Now we have had it confirmed that this $3 million is coming from the Natural Heritage Trust, I ask the minister: how can this government, which guaranteed that that money was allocated to spending on environmental works, spend it on capital works on the repair of a dam between the seats of Indi and Farrer in this coming financial year? How can it justify that?

talker.name: Parer, Sen Warwick
Senator PARER
talker.role: Resources and Energy

talk.start.para: âThe only response that I can give to the senator isâand I had suggested to him that I will refer some of the parts that I could not answer because I do not have a brief from the ministerâthat it actually comes from the program.
âMy question is directed to Senator Ellison, rather than Allison, in his capacity as the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs.

âThere is no point of order. The minister need not answer hypothetical matters which are put to him.

âThe woman was referred to three employment agencies. The first, in Gosford, had a recorded message and she gave up in frustration after 10 minutes; the second, also in Gosford, was a $20 return trip by public transport; and the third, at Wyong, was a $10 public transport trip. talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Schools, Vocational Education and Training

answer.para: Senator Neal said that job seekers are referred to providers. They do not necessarily have to go thereâthey have all that facility at Centrelink. talk.start.para: âHear, hear!

We have increased the site numbers to over 1,500. Remember I said it was over 1,400? Well it has got bigger. There is moreâit is over 1,500. That is over four times what we previously had. Things have got better for unemployed Australians.

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Schools, Vocational Education and Training

âMy question is to the Minister for Social Security. Will the minister outline the benefits to young Australians of the government's youth allowance initiative which begins today? How does the youth allowance contrast with the income support schemes left by the previous government?

talker.role: Social Security

answer.para: And yet, the Labor government, throughout 13 years, perpetuated a system where it was more attractive financially to be unemployed than to study. It is amazing that we could have a party opposite that would go on and on proposing that there is something nasty in the woodpile about the youth allowance. The benefits are clear. It is very clear that Australia will be benefited. More students will be eligible for assistance than were eligible under Austudy. That is why I make the point that the more generous income test means that there will be more families that can afford to have their children educated. It is particularly important for young people who have to come away from regional centres to get a further education. talk.start.para: âThat is quite right. You cut $500,000.
âIt seems very difficult for the opposition to allow the Australian people to hear about the benefits of the youth allowance.
âThere are 45,000 students worse off under your government.
âSenator Carr, stop shouting.

âMy question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. If this occurs, yet another primary industry faces devastation from cheap imports as well as the threat of foreign diseases devastating our fisheries. talker.name: Parer, Sen Warwick
Senator PARER
talker.role: Resources and Energy

talk.start.para: âI thank Senator Woodley for the question. I will correct an incorrect comment he made about cheap overseas imports. The salmon industry has not been concerned about competing with any imports on price; it has only been concerned about any disease that might be introduced into this country.

answer.para: Government senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âThere are senators on my right interjecting. I ask them to cease.

âThe World Trade Organisation publicly released the report of the dispute settlement panel on 12 June this year. The panel was established by the dispute settlement body of the World Trade Organisation on 10 April 1997 in response to a request from Canada. This followed Minister Anderson's announcement on 20 September 1996 of the AQIS decision to continue the quarantine restrictions on uncooked salmon on quarantine grounds.

answer.para: It would be prejudicial to Australia's interests to comment on the legal correctness or otherwise of the panel's findings. The report has not disputed Australia's right to adopt strong, scientifically based quarantine measures which are appropriate to our domestic circumstances. The Australian government will continue to protect our national interest by maintaining the policies in place to protect our very favourable animal and plant health status.

The report has three main findings which relate to Australia's risk assessment procedures, consistency in the management of quarantine risk and the application of existing measures. The panel's report is subject to appeal under the dispute settlement procedures of the World Trade Organisation. A decision on whether to appeal the panel's findings will be made in the light of detailed analysis of the report which is now under way, including consultation with the stakeholders. I also point out to Senator Woodley that an appeal can really only be based on points of law.

talk.start.para: âI thank the minister for his answer. Minister, what is the implication of the WTO decision on salmon, if it is upheld, on other Australian quarantine decisions, particularly on chicken, pork, apples and pears? talker.name: Parer, Sen Warwick
Senator PARER
talker.role: Resources and Energy

We have said on many occasions that we will continue to protect our very valuable animal and plant health status. We will continue to direct our attention in that regard. But to go down the track of introducing into this country tariff or non-tariff barriers, particularly non-tariff barriers, which would adversely affect the size of our exports overseas, would be absolutely stupid.(Time expired)

âMy question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. talker.name: Parer, Sen Warwick
Senator PARER
talker.role: Resources and Energy

If I can be helpful to him, he should phrase it in such terms as, `In such circumstances, how do you explain,' and then it would be legitimate. But in the form in which he is putting it, it is illegitimate. He should comply with the standing orders in the same way as everyone else has to.
âYour question should be phrased properly, but proceed with it, Senator Faulkner.

âOn the point of order, Madam President: I would have thought, given that I was commencing my question, that there was nothing improper in the question. I was about to conclude my question and it was perfectly in order, and I would ask you to rule accordingly.

talker.role: Environment

Senator Faulkner interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âSenator Hill, I can't hear you.
âI know why he is interrupting: it is very embarrassing. Before the last electionâ

answer.para: Honourable senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âSenator Faulkner and Senator Alston will cease talking across the chamber.

âBefore the last election he granted an enormous increase in the Roxby Downs uranium mine, and did so without even requiring an additional environmental impact statement. It was reported in the press in the following terms:

You see, that is the Green side. It continues:
But it is understood he finally agreed to sign the paperwork to avoid the South Australian Liberal government making political mileage out of the issue during the election campaign.

Just before the election, with all secrecy, a wink and a nod to Roxby Downs, but really saying to the Greens, `Don't worry, we've got the three mines policy, therefore exports are not being increased.'

So he says to the Greens, `We're on your side; it won't go ahead if we get into office.' He says to industryâinterpret exactly the same words the other wayâ`We're on your side; the mine will be allowed.'

This puzzling position of the Labor Party was put well by another well-known Labor identity last week. Perhaps not everyone in the Senate happened to be listening to 2GB on Thursday last week at 8 a.m. when that identity said:

talker.name: Parer, Sen Warwick
Senator PARER
talker.role: Resources and Energy

talk.start.para: âYesterday in question time, Senator O'Brien asked me a question, on behalf of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, in regard to pig industry assistance. I referred that question to the minister and I now have a response which I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard .

answer.para: Leave granted.
The answer read as followsâ
I refer to yesterdays question from Senator O'Brien regarding a press release from the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy entitled, "Government Announces Pig Industry Assistance."
The media statement said;
"The Government has decided to correct a surprising administrative anomaly it identified when looking at the safeguards issue."

"The previous Labor Government inexplicably failed to include such a safeguard mechanism in legislation introduced into parliament at the conclusion of the Uruguay Round of multilateral trade negotiations in 1994."
Senator O'Brien questioned whether, "the Minister agrees that the claim that legislative amendments were required was no more than a delaying tactic by the government."

Senator O'Brien, the minister never claimed that LEGISLATIVE AMENDMENTS were required, he merely highlighted the fact that the previous Labor government failed to avail itself of implementing such a mechanism, when logic suggested it should have been included in 1994 with the associated legislation.

That is precisely the point, Senator O'Brien, the previous Labor Government INEXPLICABLY FAILED to nominate a body to conduct such safeguard investigations, or even to make any mention of safeguards action, at the time.

Indeed at the Senate Estimates Committee on Wednesday 10 June, Senator Cook was questioned on the issue of implementing safeguard mechanisms during the previousâLabor government, and I quote from the transcript.
Senator HillâWho was it who missed this important opportunity to safeguard Australian industry?
Senator CookâWell, the argument is whether an important opportunity did go past to safeguard the Australian industry.
Senator HillâAnd are you arguing it did not.
Senator CookâI do not know. I was not in charge of this part of the legislation at the time.
Senator HillâAre you washing your hands of your government's failure.
Senator CookâNo, I am not. I am absolutely sure we focused on this at great length in cabinet. I am sure we devoted a whole day to debating it.
Senator HillâAnyway, we can be assured that you will cooperate with the current government now.
Senator CookâI am pretty sure you will find that we will cooperate with the current government on this initiative.
I would pose the question, was the Labor Government short sighted or did it choose to ignore the issue.
I would also pose the question to Senator O'Brien whether he has discussed with Senator Cook how he plans to cooperate with this government on this initiative.

The Government on discovering this INEXPLICABLE FAILURE to nominate a body to conduct such safeguard investigations, set about rectifying this problem as quickly as possible and I AM PLEASED TO SAY that WE HAVE FIXED the problem without the need for specific new legislation.

The fact of the matter is that the safeguards mechanism can be put in place via specific legislation or regulation, or through incorporation of the mechanism into existing domestic law. Given the commitment of this Government to address the pig industries concerns we have put in place the general procedures as an urgent priority, in a manner fully consistent with our WTO obligations.

In regard to Senator O'Brien's fallacious accusation that the government has used delaying tactics, I am pleased to assure him that is not the case, as is evidenced by the speed with which these procedures have been put in place

Indeed, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has today welcomed the finalisation of the reference from the Treasurer to the Productivity Commission for an inquiry into imports of uncooked pork and the profitability and competitiveness of the pig farming, pigmeat and processed pigmeat industries.
"The inquiry will examine whether safeguards action is warranted against imports ofâfrozen pigmeat under the WTO safeguards arrangements.

The industry asked for this inquiry and the Government has met the industry's request by setting up the required procedures for safeguards inquires and now initiating an investigation into pigmeat imports.

"It is now up to the industry to make submissions to the Commission and to present it with the evidence that substantiate its claims that safeguards measures on imports could be justified under the WTO Agreement. This is now industry's responsibility",

The Government has swiftly and decisively responded to the requests of the pig industry, and in the process it has yet again identified the previous Labor governments failure to exercise our legitimate rights under the WTO, in this case having a safeguard mechanism in place.

The accusation by Senator O'Brien that, "the 140 day reporting date for the productivity commission report is a ploy to delay any government decision until after a possible election" is noting more than blatant political opportunism.

Senator you are purporting to have a genuine interest in rural Australia when all that you are really doing is promoting yourself within your party for your own ends, with scant regard for the gravity of this issue.

The minister does not seem to think it is very important. She does not understand the sorts of income levels that are adversely affected by these changes.

speech.para: Senator Newman tries to emphasise the positives that are contained in this legislation but chooses, not only in her public declarations within this chamber but also in the $3.8 million publicity campaign, to omit the negative effect that the youth allowance and its introduction are having on a very large group of people. We are talking of about 48,000 people being affected, not just a small number. This is a situation where young adults between the ages of 18 and 21 will no longer receive unemployment benefit except where it is means tested on their family's income.

The minister tried to argue in the debate that it would only be those families who are well off who are affected by this change, but this really is not the case. Senator Newman is talking about family incomes which start at $23,400. That means a family with one income earner earning $23,400 possibly supporting a spouse and an adult childâthat is, three adults relying on an income of $23,000 or about $440 per week gross. To date, that young unemployed person would have received a payment of $87. That is not a huge amount, but it is enough to deal with their own food, maybe for them to make a bit of a contribution to the household and also for them to provide clothes to go to job interviews, pay for public transport and to make some effort to return to the paid work force.

What has occurred with these changes which are brought about by the youth allowance is that this type of family is much worse off. They lose $87 per week. If the minister truly believes that families on that sort of income bracket are well of and that they will be going around saying, `I think it is wonderful that this government has taken away our income. I'm so well off, I really don't think I deserve it,' then they should think again.

The worse thing is, with all these changes coming into effect today, the minister went out and spent $3.8 million, not $3.8 million of the minister's money, not $3.8 million that was in her personal pocket, but $3.8 million of taxpayers' money to tell everybody how wonderful the youth allowance is.

But the minister failed to tell this particular group of people who are really struggling at the moment and who have all sorts of increased costs in health, in education and in all the areas in which the Commonwealth has generally provided services that they are all paying a bit more. They are waiting longer at hospitals because of cuts by the federal government. Families are being knocked around by these changes, but the minister did not bother to tell them that Senator Newman did not have $1 out of that $3.8 million to explain to this particular group of 50,000 people that in fact they would be worse off.
This government constantly talks about honesty, it constantly talks about the cynicism of the electorate, but it fails to recognise its own failings. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âIt is amazing that we are back on this issue yet again, two days after we last discussed the matter in taking note of answers. I would have thought the people on the other side would have seen the error of their ways in relation to this matter, because what this government has introduced with the common youth allowance is a much superior system to what Labor had for 13 years. For 13 years they struggled on with a whole series of rates of pay. They had jobstart and they had Austudy, and students in this country had great difficulty moving between one and the other.

speech.para: We had a major Senate inquiry, and the Commonwealth Ombudsman found 17 major errors with the way in which the previous Labor government was administering the Austudy allowance. One of the major problems, the inquiry found, was that there was an incentive for people to go from Austudy onto the newstart allowance. In other words, if they went from study to laying on the beach, they would actually receive a higher rate of benefit and they would also be entitled to rent assistance, something they were never entitled to under the old Austudy system.

So the previous government in this country struggled on for 13 years with a ramshackle system of varying rates of benefit for people in different categories. And, when they moved between categories, they were penalised; they were fined; often, if they were overpaid, they had to pay it back in a short period of time, creating enormous hardship for them. This government has created one common youth allowance across the whole system. People do not move between categories; people do not get fined; people do not have to pay back money.

But one of the great things about this system, of course, is that we are putting a lot more money into the total system, to the point where 137,000 people will be better off. Senator Neal cannot quite get her figures right. Obviously some people will be disadvantaged under the system. But those opposite keep getting the figures wrong. The figure is actually 33,000. The group of people who are most in need are the ones whom we target benefits under a very longstanding system in Australia. I would have thought that was a principle that the Labor Party would find quite easy to support.

And if parents are able to support their own children in these circumstances, they should. But of course the people on the other side keep giving us the wrong figures. They keep trying to blow out that figure to a higher figure. The figure is 33,000. The number who are better off, who will get more money, is 137,000. And it is not just that they get more money; a lot of them are entitled to rent assistance as well.

It is great that this system is starting today. We have replaced the old system with a comprehensive system for all youth who are having difficulty finding employment or who are studying. Those who cannot find study courses will still be able to access the benefit if their courses are not available.

It is very important that the incentives in this system that we have set up direct people away from sitting back doing nothing and actually involve them in education. We are very concerned that the young people of this country who cannot find work should stay in training as long as possible. We have set up arrangements so they can do this. We have a new program whereby there will be additional resources for high schools for those who stay at school. We have set up a program whereby there will be more apprenticeships in this country. This year, of course, our universities actually over-enrolled by 29,000. So there are plenty of places right across the system for our youth.

Whether they are studying or unemployed, this common youth allowance we have set upâa properly administered, integrated system of youth supportâwill actually put more money in; it will not take it out. Under this program, the vast majority of people will be much better off.

talk.start.para: âI find it extraordinary that Senator Tierney claims that it is amazing that we are debating this issue. Of course we are debating this issue today.
âWe debated it two days ago.

âToday, 1 July, marks the introduction of the common youth allowance. Do you realiseâthrough you, Madam Deputy President, to Senator Tierneyâthat 45,000 who apparently may be eligible for those benefitsâ
âWrong!
âWrong! Wrong figure!

âstill have not put their forms in. Before you try to interrupt, Senators, and suggest that I have the wrong figure, the figure I am referring to is the number of people whose forms have not yet been put in. And I dare them to stand up and deny that figure.

speech.para: Madam Deputy President, I will tell you the figures they are referring to. When talking about 32,500 who will have reduced payments, quoting from Senator Jocelyn Newman's press release, Senator Tierney forgot to mention the 12,800 who will receive no money. That equals 45,050 people whose money will be reduced in some way, or approximately 13,000 people who will lose their benefits altogether.

From the beginning of this debate the Democrats have acknowledged the benefits of having a streamlined national income support system for young people. We know that it can lead to greater flexibility, we know it means people will not have to shuffle between departments, and we also acknowledge that the parity between unemployment benefits and student assistance is a good thing. That is why we have called for it for many years. It is only being delivered now.

However, as Senator Newman would say, there are nasties in this woodpile, and that is the fact that we are going to see a numberâtens of thousandsâof young people between 18 and 20 years of age whose benefits will be reduced. We are going to see approximately 13,000 people between the ages of 16 and 18 lose their benefits altogether. I ask you, Madam Deputy President, how those 16- and 17-year-olds not in employment, education and training are going to survive.

We are going to see the operation of an income test, a means testing arrangement for parents, that kicks in at just over $23,000 per annum. It is not a generous threshold at all. And we are seeing a redefinition of the ages of independence. If you are young and unemployed, you are not considered an adult until the age of 21; you are considered dependent on your parents until the age of 21. As for students, 25 is the age at which you will be considered independent, despite the fact that this is unlike nearly any other legislation or policy relating to income support or payments in this country today, whether it is family payments or family law.

We have also seen a $2.8 million advertising campaign that the government could not even get right. I do not deny that the government should spend money on advertising, but not on propaganda, not on propaganda that fails to mention the fact that students or young people currently eligible for Austudy or unemployment benefits, or who may be eligible under the new criteria for common youth allowance, will attract penalties if they do not get their forms in on time. There has been no clarification in this place or in any other place that some people who are current Austudy recipients may have their benefits docked by 18 per cent for six months if, for some reason, they fail to get their benefit form in by the first week of July, and yes, it is being reported that from 8 July they will be breached if current Austudy recipients do not get their forms in on time.

This is despite a promise in the form of a letter from Senator Tambling, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security, to various youth, social and other organisations that assist young people with their entitlements, that individual phone calls would be made to people who risked losing their benefits. To our knowledge, we have no examples of where those individual phone calls have taken place. It was said that two letters would be sent to people who are current recipients or who were going to be eligible under the common youth allowance system. We have heard of only one letter and, again, that letter makes no mention of the penalties that these young people may attract if they get their application forms in late.

We have seen promises, too, of an advertising campaign, both in literature and on television, that would mention these penalties. That has failed to happen. It is no coincidence that today also marks the first day that the Australian Youth Policy and Action Coalition will be operating without government funding. Yes, as of yesterday, that national peak body for young people has been defunded, and I wonder why. What a coincidence when the government is insisting on implementing a strategy that is full of nasties, that will see tens of thousands, at least over 45,000, of young people with severely reduced benefits or benefits that are cut off altogether.

It is hardly any wonder that this organisation has been defunded by this government that seems to think that young people should be seen and not heard, but certainly not paid, compensated or given a livable income or some kind of student assistance, whether it is for study or for training. This government cannot even pour adequate resources into the education and training sectors, let alone ensure that those students have enough money to live on. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âUnder this government young people are being encouraged through the common youth allowance to undertake study and not face a penalty, as young people did under the previous Labor government. It was a constant complaint of students who said, `I would be better off on unemployment benefits. I would be better off going on the dole than I am being a student.' It was constantly remarked upon by students and, of course, that was the case.

speech.para: What we have done is to introduce a common youth allowance and to bring in equity. There are going to be some winners and there are going to be some losers. Senator Stott Despoja comes in and talks about the 12,800 young people who will not receive money, but there are about 153,000 who will receive more money and about 3,600 who will receive the same money. So over half a million young people will receive the same amount of money or more under the common youth allowance. Look at the rent allowance, which is something that we have addressed because young people, especially from the bushârural kids coming down to study in the cityâwere not able to get rent allowance when they were on Austudy. We have rectified that, and it means that for some young people there will be up to $75 a fortnight to assist them in finding accommodation. That will make an enormous difference, especially to country kids being able to come to the city to study.

We also do not hear about the fact that there are 100,000 new apprenticeships available. We recognise that there are some young people who do not go on to higher education, who do not go on to university, but that we need a skilled labour force, and those young people who may have been on unemployment benefits under Labor have access to 100,000 new apprenticeships and traineeships. We will also have a school-to-work program to encourage people, to develop their skills, and to breach the gap between school and work to encourage them to find jobs rather than being on unemployment benefits.

We needed a common youth allowance. We had five payments at 13 different rates administered by two departments. As young people changed from being students to unemployed to whatever, they were moving backwards and forwards, falling between stools, and were likely to be in receipt of overpayments or underpayments as a result of that. Young people fell between the cracks if they were ill; there were all sorts of anomalies. It was complicated to administer and it was difficult to assess their entitlement.
When the youth allowance saw the light of day, there was an enormous reaction to it. I will give you an example of some of the editorials. The Herald Sun on 19 June 1997 stated:

The Federal Government's reforms to youth welfare payments are welcome . . . This age group is much too young to begin life in an environment which could lead them into the mistaken belief that the world owes them a living.
The Daily Telegraph on 18 June 1997 stated:
The Federal Government's new youth allowance program will end the rort of using the dole as pocket money for a few months and possibly a few years of loafing around.
An editorial from the Financial Review of 19 June 1997 said:

The Federal Government's decision . . . should be vigorously applauded . . . the changes . . . are weighed towards solid Australian values of responsibility and hard work . . . the existing system has clearly not worked.
The Sydney Morning Herald on 19 June 1997 stated:
the change . . . is desirable and overdue . . . In too many cases it [youth unemployment benefits] has encouraged young people to leave home prematurely and inclined them to welfare dependency.
A final quote comes from the Brotherhood of St Laurence. On 18 June 1997, they said:
We have been asking for better support for this group of young people for many years and finally their needs are starting to be recognised.

They were comments about the common youth allowance, but we have the other side carping away. They came up with no reforms on this issue in 13 years. We have here a significant proportionâ500,000âof young people who will be better off or will get the same money. There are 32,000 who will receive a reduced payment. Many of them are young people who would have been on unemployment benefits, who would have got unemployment benefits that they would not have got, or a level of benefit they would not have got with their parents on the same income, if they had been students. That is not equitable.

What we are saying is that young people should be treated equitably, based on their parents' income, and that we should not have a system which is a disincentive to study, to go on to an apprenticeship scheme or to better your skills. What we want to do is give young people the skills, the knowledge and the tools to last them into the next century. Giving them an incentive to take the dole rather than to be a student or to take up an apprenticeship is not the way to do that.

talk.start.para: âSenators on the other side have tried to justify the changes that are being introduced today, and I suppose that is their job. Senator Newman, for instance, spoke of the benefits and diverted attention away from the very specific case that was raised by Senator Forshaw. She said that she would have to get more information about that particular example.

speech.para: It is the specific examples that I am concerned about. I know that a number of senators and members of the House of Representatives are receiving many complaints, both by phone and by letter, and they know the very specific instances where people are going to be severely disadvantaged. But in this climate, in this rarefied atmosphere, you talk about what the advantages are and that there will be only a few people affected. Whether the figure that has been debated across the chamber this afternoon is 33,000 or 48,000 does not seem to matter very much, but I want honourable senators to focus on individual families, individual needs and what it is going to do to them.

I would have thought that, in the current political climate, honourable senators would have been far less keen to quote generalised statistics and would be far more concerned about the individual impact on specific families. Senator Neal quoted a figure of the loss of $87 a week. If a family on an average low income is going to lose $87 a week they are not going to be interested in hearing from coalition members that, on average, many other people will be better off. We have to look at individual needs and individual families.

I want to quote some of those examples that I have heard. For example, take the case of a family who have just been told that their 18-year-old daughter will lose all her unemployment benefits, her health care card and her public transport concessions. One parent has a chronic illness and the other earns an average wage and now they have to find an extra $87 a week to support their daughter. On top of this, the loss of the health care card means the daughter has to pay an extra $39 for her asthma inhaler and a full fare on the bus.

talk.start.para: âWhat is the parents' income?
âAll I can tell you is that this is a real case. This is not like the Wright family; this is a real case. Here is another example:

speech.para: I am 18 years old, live with my parents and currently am unemployed. As of December, my family has lived off one income of just under $28,000 per annum. Under the new legislation, my family is now means tested on past income, despite the fact that for the last six months we have been a single income family. I am now no longer eligible for any payment of any kind, health care card, etc.
I think the problem, Senator McGauran, is that there will be a whole range of circumstances that no well-intentioned bureaucrat could have considered.

The numbers of people that Senator Stott Despoja claimed have not yet returned their forms indicate that, although it is 1 July, people are not aware, despite the amount of money that has allegedly been set aside for a public relations campaign. I would like to ask the Minister, who unfortunately has not bothered to remain in the chamber for this debate, whether she has asked her department to set up any kind of process to consider an impact assessment of the changes. How is the department going to manage the various hardship cases that will arise? If we are all receiving them in our offices, I am sure the departments are going to become aware of them very soon.

I would also like to know what has happened to the $70 million that was given to the Department of Social Security, presumably to help them administer these changes. How is that money being spent, and why is it, on 1 July, we find that so few young people are really aware of what their entitlements are? There are many confused young people; there are many disillusioned families. I think the minister really needs to look very closely at some form of impact assessment and should closely monitor the impact of this policy, because I would predict that it is going to beâ(Time expired)

talk.start.para: âHere we go again. Senator Reynolds, you brought the Senate's attention to the fact that the Minister, Senator Newman, had to go and attend to ministerial business. I would like to bring the Senate's attention to the fact that the person who thought that this was important enough to raise, Senator Belinda Neal, has also seen fit to leave the chamberâthat is really a great shame. You do not want to hear the facts; you do not want the good news; you do not want to hear that we are spending $212 million more on Australia's young people.

speech.para: You know as well as anyone that attack is the best form of defence, and you are looking pretty shabby over there today. How can $212 million extra towards Australia's young people possibly be construed as something negative? It cannot; it is a great positive. I am sure that most people in the Australian community, perhaps with the exception of ALP and Australian Democrats members, would recognise that. It is a great day for our nation's young people. Today we take the incentive out of being unemployed. Today we are about targeting the benefits to those most in need. Today there are 137,000 young people who are better off, Senator Reynolds, and you hadâ

talk.start.para: âSenator Synon, would you like to address the chair, please.

âYes, thank you, Madam Deputy President. There are 137,000 young people better off. And Senator Reynoldsâwhich I thought was quite incongruousâhappened to mention that the facts were not important. I mean, `Let's talk about the incidental cases. Let's forget about the 137,000 young people who are better off. Let's talk about Susan from Newcastle.' This is about targeting assistance. This is about helping the majority of Australians.

speech.para: Today, we encourage young people to study, to stay at school, to improve their knowledge and skill base, as Senator Patterson very ably described. We all know that if you stay at school, that if you continue your education to the best of your ability, your chances of becoming unemployed are cut to a third. Is that not something that is good for Australian young people? I would like to suggest that indeed it is.

From today, rent assistance and remote area allowance are available for the first time in rural and remote areas. It is clear that the ALP currently has very little representation in rural and remote areas amongst its members of parliament. If it had it would be in this chamber applauding this decision, applauding the fact that for the first time young kids from the country are being looked after.
Now, 27.5 per cent of people are going to get more money. And you have the audacity to come into this chamber and carp about it. And 64 per cent will get the same amount of money.

A very small percentage will have reduced benefits because of more effective targeting of the social security system. If that is not enough of a positive, there is an extra $42.6 million to assist with the expected increase in school enrolments. Isn't that goodâkeeping young people at school, giving them the option to increase their knowledge and skill base to prepare them for a rapidly changing world? Well, I think today is a great day for young people. The coalition is about empowering young people to speak for themselves. Youth allowance is not a savings measure; it is costing $212 million more.

In the Herald Sun, a Victorian newspaper, last year in December we read that country teenagers drop out of high school up to 20 per cent more than their city counterparts. In general terms, 75.7 per cent of metropolitan students finish school compared with only 62.6 per cent of our country students. And why is that? Because country kids have done it very tough. And under the ALP there has been an incentive to become unemployed rather than to stay at school.

Unemployment is coming down under this government. We care. Unlike Keating, we do not yell out to Australia's young people, `Go get a job.' We have not presided over one million unemployed. We are not churning billions of dollars through Training Nation. Your record is a disgrace. We are here to spend $212 million more on unemployed people, but you complain. How typical. How pathetic.

talk.start.para: âOrder! The time for the debate has expired.

talk.start.para: âI seek leave to make a short statement.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: âThe notice of motion is self-explanatory and will clearly be dealt with tomorrow. I wanted to add a couple of points to it by way of statement. The extra sitting is required to enable the Senate to deal with essential government legislation. As far as possible, it is the government's intention that the extra sitting hours for that week be used for that purpose.
âWhat bills? Name the bills.

âI am just talking about government business. It will be clear from reading the proposal that the maximum time has been allocated to government business, although there are allocations for question time and taking note. I indicate, however, that if any notices of motion need to be given or dealt with during the weekâto disallow regulations, for exampleâleave will be given for that purpose. I also indicate that committee reports could be tabled during the week. But we indicate now that the government would not be of a mind to grant leave for motions to take note. I just make it quite clear that we are trying to maximise the amount of time available for government business during that week.

âby leaveâThe manager of government business would be aware that to date the opposition has granted the equivalent of an extra 20 weeks of government business time throughout this session. You are seeking here, I see, a substantial additional amount of time which, as you have indicated, precludes a whole lot of normally available procedural matters which are available to the opposition. There has been no discussion with the opposition on these matters. There has been no discussion with us about the prospect of our sitting late on every one of the nights next week, bar Wednesday. I think we are entitled to have an explanation as to what it is that the government is intending to debate, what the legislative program is that the government is proposing to put before the parliament which would justify the extension of hours that it is seeking.

speech.para: I think we are also entitled to have an explanation as to what the government intends to do in regard to supplementation for staff and the other resources that are required to bring personnel to Canberra so that we can maintain orderly operations as required by our parliamentary responsibilities. I gather that the government, given that it has introduced this measure and given notice on this unilateral basis, intends to proceed whether we like the measures being proposed or not. If that is the case, I expect that the government will allow plenty of time tomorrow to debate this proposal.

talk.start.para: âI give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

speech.para: That the Senateâ
(a) take action to address the Government's failure to adhere to and implement the Wood and Paper Industry Strategy of 1995;

(b) notes the Government's lack of policies and interest in preventing the loss of jobs in the forest and paper industry, such as the 250 jobs to be lost at the Burnie Pulp Mill due to Government inaction; and
(c) calls on the Government to immediately:

(i) constitute the Wood and Paper Industry Council under its original terms of reference with the appropriate funding necessary to enable it to achieve the outcomes contained in the Wood and Paper Industry Strategy,

(ii) announce an implementation timetable for the Wood and Paper Industry Strategy, with particular attention being paid to the actions that can be taken to further process and `value-add' timber in Australia,
(iii) enter into discussions with Amcor, the relevant trade unions, the Tasmania Government and the Burnie City Council to determine what actions need to take place to retain the pulp mill in Burnie,

(iv) encourage all governments in Australia to recommit to the definition of `ecologically sustainable development' contained in the National Forest Policy statement, which was signed by all Australian governments in 1992,

(v) recognise that the Australian community will not tolerate the export of largely unprocessed forest products especially logs and woodchips while our own manufacturing sector is suffering a serious decline and increasing competition from imported products sourced from forests that are not, in any way, managed on an ecologically-sustainable basis, and

(vi) implement measures legally available to ensure that any wood, pulp or paper products imported into Australia come from forests that meet applicable and internationally-certifiable environmental standards of forest management.

talk.start.para: âI give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

speech.para: That the Senateâ
(a) notes:

(i) the work being done by the Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts References Committee on the powers of the Commonwealth in environmental protection and ecologically-sustainable development in Australia, and
(ii) that the Government is shortly expected to introduce a bill into the Senate on the Commonwealth review and reform of environment legislation; and

(b) resolves that, in view of the expertise developed by the Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts References Committee in this area, the bill, or bills, after their first reading in the Senate, stand referred to that committee for inquiry and report by the last day of sitting in November 1998.

talk.start.para: âI give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

(b) notes that:

talk.start.para: âI give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

speech.para: That the Senateâ
(a) acknowledges the importance of the 20th anniversary of self-government for the Northern Territory on 1 July 1998;
(b) notes the significant cultural, social and economic development that has taken place in the Northern Territory in the past 20 years, which has benefited all Territorians;

(d) calls on the Australian Government to assist the Northern Territory Government in developing proposals for statehood, further regional engagement with Australia's Asian neighbours, resource development and the improvement of government services for health, education and aboriginal communities.

talk.start.para: âOn behalf of Senator Brown, I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, he will move:

speech.para: That the Senateâ
(a) notes moves within Indonesia and the United States of America to investigate the wealth and assets held by ex-president Suharto and his family and associates;

debateinfo.title: SOCIO-ECONOMIC CONSEQUENCES OF THE NATIONAL COMPETITION POLICY COMMITTEE

debate.para: Motion (by Senator Margetts and Senator Cook)âby leaveâproposed:
(1) That the Senate notes:

(a) the observation expressed in the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Financial Institutions and Public Administration entitled Cultivating Competition: Inquiry into aspects of the National Competition Policy Reform Package , that there has been no major analysis of the broader socio-economic costs of the National Competition Policy; and
(b) that many voters in the 1998 Queensland election indicated that they were disillusioned with economic reforms such as National Competition Policy and the broader impacts of such changes.

(2) That a select committee, to be known as the Select Committee on the Socio-Economic Consequences of the National Competition Policy, be appointed to inquire into and report, on or before the first sitting day in 1999, on the following matters:

(a) the broader socio-economic consequences, including costs, of the National Competition Policy, as implemented by the Competition Policy Reform Act 1995 , including, but not limited to, the impact of the policy on:
(i) unemployment,
(ii) changed working conditions,
(iii) social welfare,
(iv) equity,
(v) social dislocation, and
(vi) environmental impacts;
(b) the relative effect and variation in impact of the National Competition Policy on urban and rural and regional communities; and
(c) clarification of the definition of public interest and its role in the National Competition process.

(3) That the committee consist of 7 senators, 3 nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, 2 nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, 1 nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats and 1 nominated by the Greens (WA) or independent senators.

(4) That the quorum of the committee be 3 members with 1 representing the Government, 1 representing the Opposition and 1 representing either the Australian Democrats, the Greens (WA) or independent senators.
(5) That the committee may proceed to the dispatch of business notwithstanding that not all members have been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.
(6) That the chair of the committee be elected by and from the members of the committee.
(7) That the deputy chair of the committee be elected by and from the members of the committee immediately after the election of the chair.
(8) That the deputy chair act as chair when there is no chair or the chair is not present at a meeting.
(9) That, in the event of the votes on any question before the committee being equally divided, the chair, or deputy chair when acting as chair, have a casting vote.

(10) That the committee and any subcommittee have power to send for and examine persons and documents, to move from place to place, to sit in public or in private, notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives, and have leave to report from time to time its proceedings and the evidence taken and such interim recommendations as it may deem fit.

(11) That the committee have power to appoint subcommittees consisting of 3 or more of its members and to refer to any such subcommittee any of the matters which the committee is empowered to consider, and that the quorum of a subcommittee be a majority of the senators appointed to the subcommittee.

(12) That the committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the committee with the approval of the President.
(13) That the committee be empowered to print from day to day such documents and evidence as may be ordered by it and a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings as take place in public.

talk.start.para: âby leaveâI have heard from the government and, obviously, I have heard the words of Senator Kemp today in relation to the government's preferences. I would like to, first of all, thank the government for, after a year, agreeing to the fact that we as a community and as a Senate do need to look at the socioeconomic and the public interest impacts of competition policy.

speech.para: Quite clearly, the message that is coming through from the community is that it is necessary to do that, not in a couple of years time, as was suggested to me by a member of the Treasury in Western Australiaâand that is after they have implemented their side of itâbut now as it is being implemented in the processes that are going on to see whether or not we have the right checks and balances within that system.

I am very appreciative of the level of support that is now in the Senate for this inquiry, but I have to say that it is missing the point to suggest that it is an economic issue per se. There needs to be an inquiry because a growing number of people in the community are realising that the socioeconomic and public interest impacts on health and education in rural and regional Australia, as well as quality of service and access and equity, are not necessarily dollar issues. The one thing that is missing is the ability to judge those matters in terms of social impact and public interest. We believe that the set up of the original competition policy may not have been broad enough to deal with this, and dealing with public interest in terms of the market only may have missed the point.

Delivering this to the economics committee, I believe, will be self-defeating and may still leave a whole number of people in our community believing that the parliament has not given them the chance to look fully at all those issues. There will be a necessity to look at education, health and other social impacts, and I do not think one standing committee could consider all of those elements together.

I believe that the government has been prepared to support things like community standards being looked at by select committees. It is not good enough to be selective and say, `We'll support the select committees that we like, not the select committees that we don't.' Either way, it is necessary to take this opportunity and to do it right, if we can. I would like to indicate to the government that I thank them for their support for the inquiry, but I will not be able to support their amendments.

talk.start.para: âI ask that general business notice of motion No. 1191, standing in my name for today, relating to a call for an act of self-determination in West Papuaâthat is, Irian Jayaâto be supported, be taken as formal.
âIs there any objection to this motion being taken as formal?
âYes.
âThere is an objection.
âPursuant to contingent notice, I move:

speech.para: That so much of standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Brown moving a motion relating to the conduct of business of the Senate, namely a motion to give precedence to general business notice of motion No. 1191.

I have moved this motion because this is an urgent matter. The people of West Papua, or Irian Jaya, as the Indonesians call it, have been dispossessed of their freedom since the Indonesian paratroops dropped in in 1962. At the behest of people condemning this action from right around the world, there was a sham act of self-determination whereby some 1,000 representatives from different groups in the West Papuan countryside were brought together and, under the watchful eye of the army, given the opportunity to vote for integration with Indonesia in 1967, but that was the end of it. Since then, the people of West Papua have had their freedom suppressed.

There has been extraordinary repression of their culture and their indigenous way of life. There has been a takeover of vast areas of the more productive parts of their landsâwithout the people having a sayâby loggers and by thousands of transmigrants from Java and elsewhere to their west in Indonesia. To highlight the awesome difficulties that these people face, let me quote from the Guardian Weekly of just four weeks ago:

Amungme tribal leader Yosepha Alomang, a mother of 10, should be in Britain. But as she boarded the plane this month in Irian Jaya, Indonesia, to head for London and the Rio Tinto annual meeting, she was stopped by the military.

Had she come, Ms Alomang would have told the mining firm's corporate shareholders a harrowing tale of torture at the hands of the authorities. Four years ago she was imprisoned without charges, sexually abused and threatened with being shot. Held for a month in a filthy room, she was made to eat her own faeces.

Ms Alomang is one of many outspoken critics of the huge Freeport copper mine, high in the mountains of Irian Jaya, which is part-owned by Rio Tinto. For years the mine has been the centre of well-documented human rights violations against indigenous groups.

And I might add that within recent months there has been the shooting of a number of West Papuans on their own lands, in the vicinity of this giant Freeport copper mine owned by an international cartel with its head office in the United States. It is time the suppression of the rights of West Papuans was matched by an opening up of their plight to world view and a renewal of the debate about their freedoms. That is what my motion urgently seeks to do.

I have watched in horror, since I was a youth in 1962, not only at the way these people have been suppressed, but alsoâand this the worst thing of the lotâtheir case for freedom and their fight for self-determination, their culture and their lands being taken off the pages of world discourse, not least by successive Australian governments. Australia, by and large, has refused to even recognise the plight of people fleeing from West Papua to Papua New Guinea. We have, therefore, refused them access to asylum in Australia simply because they are classed as Indonesians, which they are not; they are West Papuans. Our nearest neighbours, along with the East Timorese, are suffering similar repression, torture and, really, genocide in terms of the definition of that word by the United Nations. It is an horrific story.

We cannot continue to turn a blind eye to the plight of these, our nearest neighbours. They are in a terrible position. They do not have international defenders. Their issue has been suppressed. Part of the reason that this motion should be declared formal so that it can be brought before the Senate and voted on before the Senate rises for what is ostensibly a long break leading to an election, is that at this critical time, with West Papuans demonstrating in Jakarta and elsewhere, we need to give them some support, some international backing and the force of humanitarian thinking that they have deserved for so long. Many of the students from West Papua have been recently protesting in Jakarta against what they say is the loss of 400,000 lives in their home country since the paratroopers arrived in 1962.

It is a cause that has been out of the public eye for too long. It is a cause that deserves world attention and indeed, condemnation. But more importantly, this motion calls for the people of West Papua to at last be given a proper, democratic act of self-determination. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI did listen closely to Senator Brown's case for urgency and I must say that if he had developed his case in relation to the government's mismanagement of its own legislation program, I think it may well have been more telling. It is extremely difficult, at the moment, for the Senate to understand what the government's priorities are in relation to the government's own legislation program. We had the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Ian Campbell) on his feet in the chamber a short time ago, unable to explain to the Senate why the government is proposing to have the Senate sit an extra week; unable to inform the Senate what legislation was likely to be dealt with in these five extra sitting days that the government is proposing that the Senate sit. It is those sorts of issues, along with the substantive ones, Senator Brown, that the opposition would give consideration to in this motion of urgency.

speech.para: On balance, I think the opposition's view would be that we cannot support the urgency motion that Senator Brown has moved. I want to say, for the record, on the substantive issue that the approach of the opposition to the issue of Irian Jaya is, of course, set out in a resolution that was adopted by the Labor Party at its national conference in January of this year.
For the benefit of the Senate, I will outline what that resolution says:

In the light of Australia's support for the United Nations International Decade for the World's Indigenous Peoples, Labor supports the right of the people of Irian Jaya to develop their own distinctive culture and institutions, and expresses its concern about government and commercial activities such as unrestrained logging, mining, transmi gration and expropriation of lands that impact negatively on local communities.

Labor notes reports of social unrest, environmental damage and human rights abuses associated with the activities of the Freeport mine, and urges the Australian government to ensure that Australian companies conducting operations in Irian Jaya fully respect the rights and traditions of local communities and develop and observe appropriate codes of conduct.

This resolution goes on to urge the Australian government, particularly through the government's aid program, to provide more support to local communities and non-government organisations to enable them to better protect their interests and rights.

I also inform the Senate that the resolution passed by the Labor Party's national conference concludes by calling on the Indonesian government to respond to concerns regarding conditions in Irian Jaya by allowing unhindered access by independent media and humanitarian and human rights organisations. The Labor Party went on to urge the Australian government to send a parliamentary mission to Irian Jaya to observe the situation and needs of the Irian Jayan people, including with regard to the adequate provision of drought relief, and to consult with local communities on how Australia can better assist their development.

These are important issues. Senator Brown says to the Senate that these are very significant issues. We agree that they are. The Senate now has to decide whether this motion of urgency to suspend the standing orders of the Senate ought to be supported. On balance, given that we are faced with a government totally incapable of managing the Senate's legislation program and completely divided in relation to its approach on the important national issues of the dayâpreferences for the One Nation Party, the privatisation of Telstra and the imposition of a GSTâwe have to see what the government has to say for itself. It is for that reason that we oppose the motion of urgency. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThe Australian Democrats are and always have been concerned about West Papua along with East Timor and, particularly, Aceh in Indonesia. This is probably an important topic to discuss with some reasonable urgency. I do not think it would take the Senate very longâwe have heard quite a bit already about the substantial topicâto vote on the motion if we believed it to be urgent. I am not averse to voting for this urgency motion, because I think it would be dealt with very quickly.

speech.para: The self-determination of any peoples anywhere is dear to the Democrats' hearts. As we all remember, West Papua had a vote. It was one of the very first that was ever carried out by the UN. Even the UN will now tell you that it was not the West Papuans' finest hour. Obviously, if we want a true vote for self-determination in West Papua we have to do it properly and we have to do it again. The Australian Electoral Commission is an expert at doing these things. It is invited all around the world to carry out votes in countries which are not used to having democratic votes. We could certainly request the Australian Electoral Commission to assist in such a vote. I am sure that it would do it and do it very expertly.

We believe that we should be looking at the current situation in West Papua. It is still a situation which needs review. There are still observations of torture and problems with disappearances. There are still problems not only around the mining areas but in several other areas. Aceh is another area that needs looking at. I am pleased to say that the Senate remains focused on East Timor. We support the urgency motion because I do not think it would take very long, if we did agree that it was urgent, to get a vote on the substantive motion.

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: âThe government opposes the motion to make this a matter of urgency, and not for the silly and spurious reason that Senator Faulkner raised in his diatribe. We are well used to Senator Faulkner standing up and generally lashing out vigorously on every opponent he sees. As a former manager of government business, he was quite notorious for the mismanagement of government business in the Senate. To be quite frank, for him to be standing up and giving lectures to others is quite absurd.
âYou were such a good manager that you got sacked.
âI got promoted, actually.
âYou got sacked, I thought.

âThis former failed minister for the environment continues to butt in. His record does not bear close examination. Senator Faulkner is the only minister for the environment to lose the green vote. Mind you, he had a pretty good opponent, if I remember correctly. It was a real achievement on Senator Faulkner's part to lose the green vote at the last election.

speech.para: I will not get diverted. We oppose this being made a matter of urgency. There is a very heavy program before the Senate.

talk.start.para: âWhat is it?

âSenator Carr is the Manager of Opposition Business in the Senate. No wonder John Cain mentioned Senator Carr's performance in his book. That comment causes no surprise. There are many vehicles available to Senator Brown if he wishes to debate a motion of this type. He can use what is available to him in the Senate procedures. The fact is that he has not bothered to use them. Therefore, we will not be supporting the suspension to make this a matter of urgency.

âThis matter is urgent not only because of human rights issues but also because this is the right time in history to deal with it. The transition in government means that Australia can play the right role in relation to Indonesia and support self-determination for those areas taken over in the 1970s. No less a radical spokesperson for human rights than Robert Menzies made very strong and clear statements about West Papua. These concerned whether Indonesia had the right to take the action it did and the role of the colonising powers in relation to West Papua. We have had similar statements from spokespeople regarding other actions by Indonesia in the 1970s, including war veterans. However, in relation to Irian Jaya, it is right that the Senate deals with this issue. It is right that we have the opportunity to debate it or take it to a vote. I support the motion for the suspension of standing orders.

âFirst, let me respond to Senator Kemp's remarks. He implied that management of this place was easy. He was only given the job for a few months. You should reflect back, Madam Acting Deputy President. When the Howard ministry was first formed, even though he was a shadow minister, he did not make the ministry. He missed out, if you like, on the November draft and was picked up in the March draft after a few ministerial resignations. So his own Prime Minister (Mr Howard) did not rate him too highly. He made him a parliamentary secretary and Manager of Government Business. The only way to get rid of him as Manager of Government Business, as he was so incompetent, was to promote him into the ministry. He took Senator Short's spot, so he no longer managed government business. This was one of the few moves by the Prime Minister that we welcomed. Little did we realise that Senator Campbell also would not be up to the mark.

speech.para: I think we have a problem as a chamber with constantly carrying resolutions on foreign affairs that are eventually transmitted to countries, day in, day out on a very selective basis. Yes, we care about self-determination in East Timor, and apparently in West Papua. What about the Polisario in the Western Sahara or the Albanians in Kosovo and so on?

talk.start.para: âMove the motions then.

âI am told, `Move the motions.' In the general disposition of powers and influence, the running of foreign affairs is usually left to the executive. The Senate can express a view. We have at least said, in one element of consistency that Senator Brown will not agree with, that we do not believe these resolutions should go forward without debate, because not all aspects of them would necessarily be agreed to, but some aspects might be. Therefore, the only point we now have to consider is whether this matter is urgent.

speech.para: Senator Kemp said that there are other more urgent matters, that the government's legislative program is more urgent. I wonder how Senator Brown reacts to that. Senator Brown, do you know what this urgent government program is? Have you been sent a letter saying, `We want X amount of bills passed'? Have you been told what is coming on next week? I tell you what: if you have been told, you are well in advance of the rest of us. All we saw was the discourtesy of bringing in a notice of motion today, saying that we would sit all of next week. I do not mind sitting all of next week, but what sort of preparation time can we have? Absolutely none. We do not know what is coming up next week. We have got no idea. Maybe we will give your motion priority next week, Senator. The issue of self-determination for what you term West Papua has been around for 36 years.

talk.start.para: âWhen was it last debated here?

âI have no idea when it was last debated here. Again, I do not know that a chamber composed like ours should be sending off some new foreign affairs resolution every day. You want this issue progressed. You want this matter investigated. I do not know about my colleagues, but I will try to influence them. When you put forward terms of reference for an inquiry by the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade or the Senate committee, if this is an important issue, I will do my best to convince my colleagues to have these matters examined in depth and reported to the Senate. That will be far more effective than a one-off motion which slides through and which is then sent to the ambassador of their government. They scratch their heads, saying, `Who is the Australian Senate? Is it the government or is it not the government?' As such, their knowledge of the Australian political system may not be what we desire, but it all comes back to the fact that Senator Brown has not made out a case for urgency.
