talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: âI wish to bring to the attention of the Senate and the Australian people a matter of serious concern. This issue revolves around the potential misuse of taxpayers' funds by a candidate who has the audacity to promote himself as a champion of honesty in politics. His name is Steve Gibbons and he is an ALP candidate for Bendigo. Mr Gibbons has a fax number, which is listed on the ALP's home page, for the electorate office of his current employer, the state member for Bendigo West, Bob Cameron. He has advertised a telephone number on which he can be contacted which is the same number that was attached to him in 1997 in his position as staff member for the Leader of the Opposition in Victoria, Mr John Brumby, which is a job paid for by the taxpayer.

speech.para: It is my understanding that this telephone is actually located at 40 View Street, Bendigo, which is the Bendigo Trades Hall Council. The question, therefore, is about who pays the phone calls for Mr Gibbons's campaign phone. Here we have an ALP candidate saying to the people of Bendigo `Feel free to ring me' on a phone number allocated to him as a staff member of Mr Brumby while he supposedly works for Mr Cameron. It beggars belief that Mr Gibbons is doing other than using these phones to make calls and send faxes. These questions arise: who pays the bills; who pays for the line rental; who does he work for; where does he work; where does he get the time to do any work, all at taxpayers' expense?

It is a matter of very grave concern that a candidate for a federal seat in the upcoming federal election could be misusing telephone and fax services provided to the Victorian parliament by the taxpayers of Victoria. It is a matter that requires full investigation into what, on the face of it, would appear to be a blatant and systematic abuse of the resources and funds of the taxpayer.

Labor, of course, continues to mislead the Australian people, spreading misinformation and running scare campaigns. It is doing its best to whip up the pro-Hanson fervour that exists on issues such as Australia Post and taxation reform. We have candidates endorsed by the ALP with an anything-goes mentality. This is one of the longest running games on that side of politics that you could ever come across. These people are fully funded by the trade union movement on the one hand, and work in a state or federal member's office on the other, yet they run around holding themselves out for office as though they are somehow poor and in need of help. This is another classic example and a matter of very great concern to the voters of Bendigo, who I can assure you will very much take these matters into account at the relevant time.

talk.start.para: âI want to talk about a matter in my state that relates to the potential employment of around 100 people. The fact that it has not occurred, as I will try to explain, borders on possibly corrupt criminal activity. I do not say that lightly. It relates to a person who came to the state with a proposal to construct two sawmills, one in the north-west of Tasmania, which is actually three-parts constructed, and the other at Bridgewater in the south of Tasmania. The person proposed to operate those mills and source wood for them from the Forestry Corporation or Forestry Tasmania, primarily from crown forests. He proceeded down the path of establishing an agreement with Forestry Tasmania.

speech.para: As a result of his not meeting what are normally set down as milestonesâin fact, he had actually got some 24 to 30 days behind on one milestoneâForestry Tasmania terminated the agreement. The person concerned said that he would take them to court. They subsequently commenced a court action of their own to verify that the termination of the agreement was actually legalâthat is, that they had legally terminated an agreement.

I reiterate to the Senate that this occurred in a state which has in excess of 12 per cent unemployment. One would think that a public body such as the Forestry Corporation would do everything possible within its charter to encourage employment, but not in this instance.

We have to understand why. The person concerned is not in the club of forest industry people in Tasmania. He actually proposed a whole new range of objectives for forestry in Tasmania which would see far greater utilisation of the resource currently being woodchipped. I can recall saying to him back in 1992 that I doubted whether he would ultimately be able to proceed. He feltâI was the secretary of the Timber Workers Union at the timeâthat I had a somewhat cynical industrial view and had no faith in some of the companies concerned.

Coming back to the issue that relates very clearly to this court case, it is now my viewâand it was my view at the timeâthat, with regard to the court case that was ultimately held, and appealed, the Full Bench of the Supreme Court in Tasmania which found in favour of Forestry Tasmania erred in their judgment. I say that on the basis of evidence that has now come to hand.

Not only has the Forestry Corporation taken this person to court, but they have pursued him on the basis of trying to make him a bankrupt, so that he is unable to continue with legal action. Again, that is occurring in a state which has in excess of 12 per cent unemployment. This is in an industry which can do with all the jobs it can possibly get.

If Forestry Tasmania are not totally inept, then they are corrupt. I do not say that lightly. There is a whole chain of events which I do not have time to mention here tonight, but I intend, over time, to bring into this chamber a series of evidence that I believe will prove that the Forestry Corporation of Tasmania is corrupt. There can be no other explanation if you follow the chain of events and, indeed, the evidence that is available.

By way of evidence, the Forest Practices Board wrote a letter to this person and provided a report to the federal Department of Primary Industries and Energy with regard to the utilisation of the resource. They are obliged under the act to verify or to clarify that sawlogs that are specified under the Tasmanian Forestry Act are not being woodchipped. They, as I

said, sent a report to the federal department with regard to a woodchip mill in the north-west of Tasmania known as the Hampshire woodchip mill. They said in that report that since the inception of the mill, only two category 2 sawlogs had been found to have turned up at the mill.

The reality is a long way from that. I have photographic and video evidence that will contradict that. At least 30 per cent of the timber going into that chip mill would meet the specifications for sawlog in Tasmania. If you ran the ruler over it with regard to sawlog specifications in any other state that conducts a hardwood sawmilling industry, you could take that up to at least 40 per cent, and possibly higher.

It is a disgraceful waste of a valuable resource. More importantly, it is even more disgraceful when you look at the circumstances that we find ourselves in with regard to the company that is endeavouring to set up a sawmilling operation in my state and employ people in my state. It is totally unacceptable on the part of the state government, with whom I took this issue upâthe premier and the minister for forests.

I make one brief comment with regard to the minister for forests. He was asked a question in what is known as the state's estimates process. They do not call it that, but that is in effect what it is. He was asked a question, with the Chief Commissioner of Forests, Mr Evan Rolley, present. The question was: could the minister and his officer advise the committee what volume of category 2 sawlogs are produced compared with that which are sold? Of course, you would expect the minister for forests to have some understanding of that. His response was, `Well, what's the difference?' This bloke happens to be a farmer at the same time. I think he grows spuds occasionally. There is a significant difference between what is produced when you cut trees down and what you actually sell.

Forestry Tasmania sells, on average, around 70,000 to 80,000 tonnes of category 2 sawlogs per annum. They tried to convey in that committee that the volume that they sell is the volume that they produce. I have spoken to every other forestry corporation in this country. If you have log specifications, with category 1 being the top and category 2 being the next level of specification, nowhere do you get the same result.

Indeed, many people in the Tasmanian industry will tell you, as will people in every other state that has a hardwood forest industry, that where you have the top category sawlog and you go to the next level of specification, the rule of thumb is this: you get two of category 2 for every category 1. But oh no, not in Tasmania. We cannot even get 10 per cent of category 1, not two for one. That is a major problem. That is why I say there is corruption because you cannot be that useless, that inept. That is why corruption exists in the Tasmanian Forestry Corporation. It should be rooted out and I hope at some stage the state government, the state opposition and the Tasmanian Greens will take effective action to ensure that it is.

talk.start.para: âI commend Senator Murphy for his presentation to the Senate. He and I have been old sparring partners on either side of the debate about the conservation of Tasmania forests, but the matter he has brought before the Senate is as a result of a long period of study. It leads him to the same conclusion that I have reached, that there is the need for an inquiry into the past practices of Forestry Tasmania and to discover to what degree corruption has occurred in those processes.

speech.para: I need only point to the fact that in the years between 1970âfollowing the advent of the export woodchip industry in Tasmaniaâand 1990, Forestry Tasmania accrued a debt of between $250 million and $500 million for selling the trees in Tasmaniaâtrees which were owned by the public and cost it nothingâto the big woodchip corporations to be exported to Japan. We were actually paying to have our grand forests cut down and exported. I do not think much has changed since then.

Moreover, despite repeated forest agreements by Labor and Liberal, we have seen the continued shedding of jobs, not least jobs out of the pulping component of the downstream manufacture in Tasmania, while trees are increasingly exported as whole logs, and woodchips are exported in increasing amounts without downstream processing, to northern hemisphere countries where jobs are created and downstream processing occurs, so that the profit goes to corporations elsewhere in the world and not back into Tasmania. The basic fault in Tasmanian politics is that weak-kneed politicians have allowed this to happen in successive Labor and Liberal governments. So whilst Tasmania is one of the biggest exporters per capita of any of the Australian states, it has the lowest per capita income.

On Senator Murphy's last reference, let me say that the Greens are ready, willing and able to pursue a full inquiry into Forestry Tasmania to the level of a royal commission, if his Labor Party will come aboard and move to join in such an inquiry. I give Senator Murphy that commitment. The numbers are there in the Tasmanian parliament now for an inquiry at that level, if Senator Murphy can get his Labor colleagues to be as brave as he is in bringing these important matters into the state parliament and acting on them.

I want to talk about what appears to be another matter for corruption involving not this country but exploiters in another country, namely, Norway. I have in my hand a letter sent to Geoff Law of my office from the Tasmanian Conservation Trust's Alistair Graham. The letter is headed `Allegation of conspiracy between Ravenor Overseas Inc. and Bergenspanken to evade penalisation under the Australian fisheries law'âBergenspanken is a bank. The first paragraph says:

As discussed, herewith some information on what I believe to be a conspiracy between the Ravenor Overseas Inc., owner of the Aliza Glacial (the longliner intercepted by the Australian Navy and arrested by AFMA on 17 October 1997 and charged with fishing illegally in the Heard Island EEZ)â
that is the exclusive economic zoneâ
and the Bergenspanken (a small regional bank in Norway which has loaned Ravenor some US$6M to buy the Aliza Glacial secured against a mortgage over the boat).

In short, what has occurred here is that Australia has impounded this Norwegian fishing vessel which is exploiting the fisheries of the southern oceans, in this case within the Heard Island EEZ. Under naval policing, the boat has been brought to Australia and impounded. But what has happened is that this small bank has, in effect, said, `The company that owns that boat has gone bankrupt. We foreclose on the boat.' It appears, under international arrangements, they may indeed be able to take the boat out of Australian waters and back to Norway. The documents that I have here are a prima facie case of a conspiracy of the worst order which precedes the impounding of that boat, whereby this situation of the boat being seized for illegal fishing was foreseen and this arrangement for the company to go bankrupt and the boat then to be seized on behalf of the bank and taken back to Norway was plotted. It is an extraordinarily serious charge.
I seek leave of the Senate to table these documents. I am grateful to the government, the opposition and other parties for indicating that that leave will be granted.
Leave granted.

subdebateinfo.title: Allegations of Human Rights Abuses in Irian Jaya
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1187)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 13 May 1998:

question.para: With reference to the villages of Bella and Alama, Ilaga district in Paniai:
(1) Was a massacre committed in these villages by the Indonesian army or Indonesian soldiers in late 1996 or early 1997; if so, will the Australian Government condemn the massacre.
(2) What steps will the Australian Government take to ensure that the Red Cross is given access to the area where the massacre is alleged to have occurred.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator Hill
talker.role: Environment

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

answer.para: (1) The Government is aware of the report on human rights violations in Irian Jaya issued in May 1998 by three Indonesia-based churches. The allegations contained in that report are, of course, deeply disturbing. The Government has taken up the allegations made in the report with a number of Indonesian interlocutors. On 2 June, Australia's Army Attache in Jakarta raised the Australian Government's concern about the allegations with Chief of Indonesia's Military Intelligence organisation. Officers from the Australian Embassy in Jakarta have also discussed the allegations with the ICRC, the Indonesian Institute of Community Studies and Advocacy (ELSAM) and local church groups.

Representatives from the Indonesian Commission for Human Rights (KOMNAS HAM) visited Irian Jaya 12-14 June 1998 to investigate the allegations of violations in the region. KOMNAS HAM announced on 15 June that it believed that human rights abuses had occurred and that it intended to undertake shortly a second visit to Irian Jaya in order to investigate more closely the allegations. The Australian Government welcomes the KOMNAS HAM investigations into the allegations of abuse.

(2) The ICRC is responsible for the distribution of humanitarian drought relief in the region in which the violations allegedly took place in 1996-97, and has access to the vast majority of those villages. However, following the OPM hostage-taking incident in January 1996, in which the OPM killed two Indonesian hostages, the military restricted access by NGOs to several of the villages in the region for fear of a repeat of the hostage-taking incident.

This is clearly a complex issue. While the Australian Government shares concerns regarding a possible repeat of the 1996 hostage incident, it also supports the ICRC's unfettered access to remote Irianese villages both in terms of allowing it to deliver humanitarian relief to drought effected villages and more broadly in its ongoing human rights role. This is a matter which we will ask the Embassy to take up with the Indonesian Government.

While there is no evidence to suggest that the alleged deaths were carried out as a result of a deliberate ABRI policy, inadequate training and indiscipline amongst the military are often factors in human rights abuses. While it is regrettable that human rights abuse by individual ABRI members continue to occur, it is notable that such behaviour is now more likely to be investigated by the Indonesian Government, and the perpetrators brought to account.

The Government views human rights as an inseparable part of Australia's overall foreign policy approach, both because the treatment of human beings is a matter of concern to Australians and because promoting and protecting human rights underpins Australia's broader security and economic interests. The Australian Government backs up this policy with a range of practical support measures, aimed at bolstering the ability of those organisations in Indonesia which are trying to address human rights concerns through monitoring, advocacy, training and education.

Australia is providing practical assistance to Indonesia in the area of institutional strengthening and good governance, in order to assist Indonesians to develop their own political, legal and human rights institutions. This assistance provides practical, concrete and realisable benefits and better equips Indonesians to address the issues they are facing. The Australian Government recently announced a grant of $2 million of assistance to the Indonesian Human Rights Commission (KOMNAS HAM) for a program of institutional strengthening and technical assistance and English training for KOMNAS HAM personnel. This assistance package results from an AusAID commissioned needs assessment. In addition, a key aim of AusAID's ongoing Specialised Training Project is to promote good governance in Indonesia. Training provided under this program will include human rights training for KOMNAS HAM staff and other Indonesian Government Agencies. Practical assistance has also been provided to the Indonesian Legal Aid Foundation, Indonesian Institute of Community Studies and Advocacy and community and human rights defenders. The Government has provided $20,000 to the Centre for Human Rights Studies (YAPUSHAM) to enable it to publish six issue of "Index" (a comprehensive compilation of human rights violations reported in Indonesia) and four issues of the journal "Imparsial" (a potentially valuable vehicle for the dissemination of human rights ideas and issues for the development of a more informed human rights debate). The Government also recently announced a grant of $2 million to assist the KOMNAS HAM.

General Government funding for governance and human rights activities will increase by $14 million (18%) to $82 million in 1998-99. This includes a five-fold increase in the Human Rights Fund which provides practical support for small, community-based projects that promote and protect human rights

The Australian Government continues to urge the Indonesian Government and military to exercise restraint in its dealings with all Indonesian citizens. The Australian Government believes that a valuable contribution made by our defence relationship with Indonesia in addressing issues of human rights is in the form of the transfer of values such as professionalism and discipline, and greater understanding of international humanitarian law and the legal and doctrinal basis of the relationship between civil and military law in Australia. By participating in training and exercises with the Australian Defence Forces, ABRI personnel are exposed to Australian values and approaches. In this way Australia can make a contribution to spreading awareness of human rights and their significance in the development of military discipline and professionalism. Only through long-term, persistent engagement with Indonesia, and its armed forces, will the effects of this transfer of values be effective.

The Australian Government continues to take a close interest in the well-being of the Irianese people. The Australian Ambassador visited Irian Jaya on 7-10 May 1998 as part of the Embassy's regular tours of the provinces of Indonesia. He was accompanied by a delegation of Embassy officers, including aid and defence officials. Another senior Embassy official visited the province in early April. In late 1997, Australia contributed a total of $3.3 million to provide assistance to the victims of drought in Irian Jaya, including $2.5 million to the ICRC operations in the province. In 1998 Australia contributed a further contribution of up to $10 million to cover drought relief operations in Irian Jaya through a joint exercise between ADF, AusAID and ABRI to deliver food supplies to remote villages. This operation is continuing.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 19 May 1998:

question.para: (1) Is the Minister aware that the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) has announced (ATO ruling 97/D20) that from 1 January 1998 students receiving Austudy and Abstudy will be excluded from claiming self education expenses as tax deductions.

(2) Can an explanation be supplied of the policy behind this decision, given that Austudy and Abstudy payments are well below the Henderson poverty line and many students rely on their self-education taxation claims to assist them in their ability to study.

(3) Can it be confirmed whether this taxation ruling will apply to people in receipt of the new Youth Allowance payment, which is designed to enable young people to move between employment and study: if so: (a) how will it apply; and (b) how will it apply to those over 25 in receipt of the new Austudy payment.

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator Kemp
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows

answer.para: (1) Yes, I am aware that the ATO issued a draft taxation ruling, TR 97/D20, which suggests that self education expenses are not deductible against Austudy and Abstudy allowances. The Commissioner of Taxation has advised me that TR 97/D20 has now issued as a final ruling, TR98/0. The final ruling issued on 17 June 1998. The draft ruling announced that from 1 January 1998 students receiving assistance payments would not be entitled to a deduction for self education expenses associated with a course of study. After receiving submissions from students, educational institutions and stake holders on this issue, the ATO has deferred the date of operation to 1 July 1998. This will benefit students receiving payments under assistance schemes as they will be able to claim self-education expenses for the full 1997-98 income year.
(2) The Commissioner also advised me that the change in the ATO's view of the law came about following a review of the law related to deductions for self-education expenses.

As a result of the review, the ATO took the view that the essential nature of self-education expenses for recipients of assistance payments relates to undertaking the study to enable a possible future income-earning activity to be commenced, not the derivation of Austudy and other similar assistance payments that may be available as an incident of the study. In other words, the ATO considers that self education expenses are not incurred in earning education assistance allowances, which are received because a student is enrolled in a course of study and satisfies eligibility criteria. As well as that, no deduction is allowable if a person's study, viewed objectively, is designed to enable a taxpayer to get employment, to obtain new employment or to open up a new income-earning activity. A full explanation of the reasons for this view is included in the final ruling.

It should be noted that students who are not in receipt of Austudy or other similar assistance are also not allowed deductions for self-education expenses designed to open up a new income-earning field.

While deductions for self education expenses may not be available to Austudy and Abstudy students, there is a special tax rebate available to them, which ensures that those students whose only income is from Austudy or Abstudy do not pay any tax at all. The ATO ruling has no detrimental effect for those students.
(3) The same general principles would apply to the new Youth Allowance Scheme.
